reviewText: Think of this as a B movie video game. The story is great, but very cliche until the very end. The combat is pretty common for a shooter, nothing amazing. I did have fun in the long run. There were some amazing boss fights and the art design was gorgeous.  Sadly the game has some big downsides that might scare people off. The major ones I ran into was with the controls. The game wouldn't let me remap left shift, and often it gave me the wrong button prompts during timed events. Finally there's a few auto scroller sections that you can tell were not made or changed at all for mouse and keyboard. One of the worst ones was with a speed boat. It tells you to use A and D to move left to right, but once pushing them it's not just a little move, but a drastic shift. Hit the walls too many times and you need to retry. I did this around 10 times before finding my brothers Xbox controller. First try with a controller I got it. You could lightly press left or right and move just slightly, unlike with A and D which are counted as full button inputs left or right.\n\nMyself, I wish there was a Muh rating. I had fun and didn't totally hate it, but I wouldn't force people out to buy it. On the other hand it's not total trash and wouldn't tell anyone no if they did want to pick it up. Again think of it as a B movie. It's fun even with all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ parts.

reviewText:
If you’re a sucker for very Japanese games, the name Yakuza Studio rings a bell. The developer team, associated with SEGA, has created the “Ryu ga Gotoku” series, known as Yakuza in the west.

East & West united: Gundam meets Blade Runner

No need to study an entire Yakuza encyclopedia this time: “Binary Domain” draws heavily from the western SciFi genre (most prominently: cyberpunk classic Blade Runner), making the squad-based shooter a more universally accessible affair. Similar to Ridley Scott’s neon-colored dystopia “Binary Domain” is set in a not-so-distant future. In the late 21st century technology has taken giant leaps, but of course, everything else is straight down the gutter: Global warming, rising sea levels, poverty… you name it, “Binary Domain” has it. With worldwide population significantly decimated, robots had to be used as the main labor force to build new cities, and they also came in handy as domestic servants or kids’ playmates. But the pro-robot-agenda has ceased since Japanese-made “Hollow Children” – almost indistinguishable from humans and potentially violent – kept appearing. The countermeasure? The “New Geneva Convention”: Prohibiting production and distribution of human-like robots. Needless to say, actually being a “Hollow Child” yourself – even without knowing it – hasn’t become the smartest idea since.

Heroes from Hollywood subs’ bench

As Dan Marshall you’re a member of the “Rust Crew”, an international task force that deals with violations of the “New Geneva Convention”. Dan is portrayed as your stereotypical, loudmouthed, hot-headed American as seen in countless Hollywood productions. If this is Team Yakuza’s potshot at one-dimensional American movie protagonists it turned out quite well. While the story touches upon rather serious issues (racism, xenophobia, human greed and megalomania), Dan and his allies don’t hesitate to frequently pull off cheesy one-liners at the most inappropriate time. With that “so-bad-it’s-good”-charm it captures the overall Hollywood (semi-)Blockbuster feel of the game.
Your mission in futuristic Tokyo is to localize and capture scientist Youji Amada, head of the Amada Corporation and persona non grata in terms of illegal production of “Hollow Children”.

Derivatively awesome

Familiar with cover-based action games like “Mass Effect” or “Gears of War”? Then “Binary Domain” does in fact feel like your standard fare. It doesn’t bring anything new to the table, save for the voice input feature. Recognizing six different languages you can use a mic to give your squad members basic commands. It’s nice having it just for the sake of it, but since the possibilities are very limited you’re just as good off sticking with keyboard inputs. Every now and then you’re prompted to react to what your team-mates are saying. We’re not speaking “Mass-Effect”-type consequences here, but depending on your choices your allies will behave more positively or negatively towards you.

Derivative as it might be – with its linear level design and the occasional QTE – “Binary Domain” happens to be an immersive experience. The production values are on par with AAA titles like “Mass Effect” or “Max Payne 3″ and the pacing is so well executed that it just feels like an interactive Hollywood action movie – which, depending on your taste, might be a good or bad thing. But, it’s perfectly evident that Team Yakuza’s ambition to create something huge is there, and that has to be acknowledged, whether you think the core gameplay is fun or not. Essentially you solely clear corridors of foes, watch a cutscene, repeat that process and eventually stumble upon a larger-than-life Mecha boss. But at least it seems that “Binary Domain” is perfectly aware of its limitations. It succeeds in presenting you the little that it has in the most possibly appealing way. Give “Binary Domain” a shot. It was my personal 2012 sleeper hit!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Remember Snatcher? The awesome cyberpunk Visual Novel that was pretty much Hideo Kojima's Blade Runner?

If Snatcher and Metal Gear had a baby, and that baby was raised by a family of wild Japanese third person shooters, you wouldn't get Mowgli, you'd get Binary Domain.

Yes, the graphics are a little bland, the character archetypes are a little cliche and the soundtrack, while engaging, is pretty generic, but it's an interesting and shockingly non-linear interactive movie masquerading as a shooter. Too bad it's not likely to get the sequel it deserves.

reviewText:
There is a sequence when you hold off enemies so your squadmate can take a dump in the restroom. What more you need to know?

This game has a thought-provoking and nicely realised world where robots have replaced menial workers and are now keen on replacing more humans, too. The philosophical bits are interspersed with solid action movie humor and cheesy action movie cliches.

Gameplay wise it's a pretty standard third-person console shooter. The bosses are huge,colorful, and interesting to fight, while the mooks (and 95% of the enemies in the game are the same mook) provide much more combat variety than you might expect.

There is a pretense of voice control, but is entirely duplicated by key commands and, I guess, was just a gimmick to tie in console voice control features.

XBOX360 controller not required, but recommended.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: A great 3rd person shooter, coming back to one of the most classic science fiction questions. Fast-paced combat, memorable bosses, companion trust system that's based on your actions in field as much as on dialogues, a possibility to give orders to companions  via your microphone, fluid gameplay coupled with rpg elements, all of that make that game one of the best 3rd person shooters out there. Also, it is extremely satisfying to shoot a robot's legs off and watch it crawl in your direction.

reviewText:
On the surface it's what looks to be like a cheap Gears of War clone.
After my playthrough I felt that this game held a story that was interesting and my influence on the growth of the characters and the impact on the story was undeniably cool.
Mechanically the game does function like a standard 3rd person shooter, but your aim is what sets it apart from others.
Attacking enemy robots in particular ways can yield better results and bigger combos.
Robot design is another positive aspect, each large robot had meticulous detail and they look amazing.

The game does mention co-op, but it is only for a horde mode like multiplayer.
A shame, game could have only benefited from co-op story. Still a solid game no matter.
An underrated sleeper hit. It's nice when SEGA takes risks like this.

reviewText: One of the best if not the best third person shooter I've ever played, it has really satisfying combat where you can shoot specific parts of the robots that have different effects, like shooting the legs making them fall, shooting their heads making them turn on their friends, shooting their arms lowering their accuracy, etc. A cast of interesting characters to pick and choose from that have different dialogues and with a trust mechanic that encourages switching them up, multiple endings depending on your trust levels and choices, and an actually interesting storyline about a somewhat cyberpunk and isolationist japan, body snatchers, killer robots and great bosses, this game is a must have for anyone who likes shooters, I completely recommend it, 10/10

reviewText:
Positive
+ Gameplay-wise the game handles the ol’ shoot-and-cover mechanics of third-person shooters extremely well, and the implemented trust system--while simple in practice--does influence elements of the story, which gives it some purpose
+ A likeable cast of party members and characters with some solid voice acting and amusing dialogue makes the surprisingly intriguing story that little bit more enjoyable
+ High quality textures mixed with great rain and lighting effects; add in some impressive set pieces and cinematics, and overall the graphical prowess for the game is high
+ Lengthy game for the modern era of shooters (around 9 hours on Survivor difficulty).


Negative
- Some of the boss fights, while impressive in scale, simply drag out for too long
- Upgrade system is fairly basic--not necessarily bad--but nothing new nor impressive.


Verdict
“One of the most surprisingly impressive third-person shooters I’ve ever played. It takes a well-known formula, and adds minor tweaks here and there to create a truly underrated gem from the past few years. Definitely a shooter worth checking out.”

8/10 TJBs

reviewText: Binary Domain is rough around the edges, but underneath that rough exterior, lies one of the most engrossing games of the previous generation. Binary Domain is a love-letter to classic Cyberpunk, such as Blade Runner and Ghost in the Shell, as well as the works of Isaac Asimov, and films like The Terminator. Gameplay is a bog-standard third person, cover shooter, affair (with a speech-command gimmick that doesn't work too well), but where this game truly shines is its characters and setting. Based in a futuristic setting where global flooding has devestated the world, Binary Domain explores themes such as classism and racism/dehumanisation under the backdrop of an isolationist, class-divided Tokyo. The game featues a cast of fully fleshed out characters, whom you can't help but become attached to, with some of the cheesiest one-liners seen since an 80's action movie.\n\nHighly recommended to all fans of science fiction, and cyberpunk in particular.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I saw reviews of this game when it came out and thought it was pretty cool. After a while, I bought it on Steam and boy, what a game it is!

Binary Domain takes on the mechanics of classic Gears of War and throws in a highly-engaging storyline with some great character development and nice twists in a futuristic setting that Isaac Asimov or Arthur C. Clarke would dream up. It's got some great run-and-gun mechanics, annoying but challenging boss fights, and manages to switch up things pretty nicely every once in a while. You'll be shooting behind cover, then speeding on jet-skis, firing from a car, using an anti-tank turret, and even hack into one of the big robots to let all hell loose! The action is so intense that you'll constantly be on edge and run straight into fights with your adrenaline pumping.

The game suffers from a few flaws, namely the voice recognition system, certain UI peeves and a bit of stiffness with regards to controls. However, this is in no way a deal-breaker. What you have here is an extremely fun game that you will be looking forward to once you wrap yourself around some of its nuances and ignore a few of the systems.

I'd highly recommend any action-game afficionado to pick this one up either on sale or through a bundle. It's a game that you definitely will not regret adding to your collection.

reviewText:
I just completed the game and felt that I needed to post some words about the game.
Little tidbit, before finer points, I fully recommend Normal on your first play through. And I'm a person that plays everything on Hard.

Combat:
Mix of mass effect, gears, and vanquish
Shooting feels excellent, although it does favor an xbox controller vs pc controls
Controller w/ aim-assist off is quite nice

Mechanics:
Light RPG mechanics, party system is a tad light
Dialog can be both interesting and a chore, so i'll say mixed at best

Story:
Intruiging, some good questions raised about man vs machine

Acting:
Very very rough, although, it might have been the script rather than the performances

Graphics:
I was actually shocked how good it looked, not bleeding edge, but very impressive for a smaller game

PC Performance:
The Game ran excellently, and had decent configration options

I highly reccommend this hidden gem of a game. If you come in withreserved expectations, you might find that this game will grab you more than you thought it would.

reviewText:
Binary Domain surprised me with one of the best cyberpunk stories in games, and well-told to boot. The acting is good, motion-captured animation nuanced and natural, graphics and design reflecting the developer's high production values. The game keeps a light tone with plenty of humour and has multiple endings depending on your relationship with your crewmates.

In terms of gameplay, Binary Domain is a typical third-person shooter, mixed up with boss fights and set changes. The controls give away a console port; the default scheme is unconventional but eventually easy to use. You determine the make-up of your team, and the characters chat with you and each other. You can gain their trust by displaying competence in battle, talking to them, and avoiding shooting them in the back. When you give orders, they obey more readily the more they trust you.

There is an optional voice recognition feature for barking orders to your crewmates, but it could not tell my voice apart from keyboard strokes. No big loss—most times, the only request I have for them is to avoid jumping in front of my gun, and they mostly keep from doing that without being told. Besides, you can give the same commands from the keyboard.

In summary, Binary Domain is a polished third-person shooter with an unusually good storyline but some rough edges around porting the interface to PC.

reviewText:
How the ♥♥♥♥ I never heard about this game is beyond me. It´s a hidden, underrated gem.

It´s good. The story is kinda like an over the top 80´s movie, and I love it. It´s not really supposed to be taken entirely seriously, however, great voice acting, characterization and overall interaction will keep you hooked. And the basic concept of the Hollow Children makes it really interesting.

The graphics are amazing considering the game was released in 2012.

Gameplay is great. It´s kinda like Gears of War, but I honestly feel this is better. However, the AI tends to be a little dumb, and love to take their time when you´re down and want them to heal you.
Speaking of gameplay, the game has a really interesting voice commands feature. You can of course use the keyboard, but there´s an option to use your mic. But I don´t know if it didn´t work very well because of my ♥♥♥♥♥♥ laptop mic, or if it was something else, but if you have a great mic, I´m pretty sure you would have no problem, and the game will be 10 times for fun.

I´d talk about the multiplayer, but it´s pretty much dead.

Really well optimized, great 8-10 hour long campaing and great gameplay makes this game worth it. Get it if it´s like 50% off and up.

8/10

reviewText:
OK, the shooting is lackluster - not exactly satisfying. The voice control gimmick doesn't work. The graphics may not be the best now. The jet ski part sucked because of controls. After all, it's not a perfect console port.

But holy ♥♥♥♥, I want a sequel. The setting is quite atmospheric. The characters are memorable (except Rachel, but maybe that's because I never took her because she's ugly), and actually the writing is pretty good. Okay, it gets predictable, but still is surprisingly good. And that's the strongest point of this game - the story.

I think it's one of the most underrated and underplayed games of 2012. And it's really weird - that year not many good games came out. Maybe people were just too busy with meh-tier blockbusters, like Far Cry 3.

reviewText:
Decent game but really bad port.

There is only anti-aliasing, shadow quality (the PS3 shadows were pretty bad and jaggy), the SSAO quality, motion blur and vertical sync. What is really annoying is how the game automatically assumes that you will be playing on an xbox controller. It's amazing. As soon as you start the game all of the instructions are given with the xbox buttons. I beat my head against the wall as I tried figuring out which key did what. So I had to quit the game and go into configuration menu to figure out how to play the damn game.

The main pillar of this game is the gameplay. It's pretty fluid but I still find the consolized running slightly sluggish. The first 20 minutes of the game are kind of boring and slow but the game gradually picks up the pace. The plot is convoluted at first but you eventually realize the gravity of the invasion of the dormant sleeper cyborgs which is pretty cool.

Back to the gameplay, there are the usual steps like take cover, shoot, gather the pulse charge, throw the grenade AND.... order your teammates to either cover you, advance or hold the ground. At the very beginning of the game the trust level between you and your team mates is pretty low though so do not expect them to always follow your orders. For instance if you tell them to charge the advancing robots, your partner will basically tell you off.

Well, the story is okay. There are a few good dramatic moments. The story not only focuses on you and your team mates but also on the gangs and the law enforcement. So it is nice to see the game world unfold through different vantage points. You get to interact with your team mates as well as other miscellaneous characters during the game. You can choose different dialogue options the outcome of which will influence your team mates' level of trust towards you.

There are annoyances though. Most of the time your AI team mates will keep saying the same thing over and over again should you venture away from them. They will say things like Sam
hoursPlayed: you are going the wrong way"
voteText: "Sam
helpfulPercent: what are you doing? Grab that grenade launcher".\n\nSo yeah

votesFunny:

I was really hoping they would tweak the PC version better and give us the opportunity to get rid of music for maximum immersion. This kind of thing ruins many games for me. I mean it is EASY to implement that option in games.

I felt like some of the checkpoints were not equally balanced. I had to restart my progress way back because the checkpoint was placed way to far. Such examples include the water chase stage and the highway chase stage.

The water looks atrocious

reviewText:
Binary Domain
Binary Domain is a 3rd person cover shooter with squad mechanics. It takes place on futuristic earth (Japan) where iRobots are rising up in rebellion against humans, yay! Sadly that's as good as the plot gets. There's decent voice acting. However the characters are basically just borrowed from other action franchises, renamed, and thrown into a squad for this game. There are some really cool robot designs, especially with the boss robots. There's a loadout system, where you add nanomachines to your rig, however they don't make a noticeable difference, and can be completely ignored. Your in game money is better spent upgrading your gun. Thumbs up on the gameplay. Binary Domain is a 3rd person cover shooter, and it does pretty well at it. Having once been an Xbox guy, it's safe to say I own all of the Gears of War titles. I know a good cover shooter. Binary Domain is not GOW, don't expect it to be, but its the best 3rd person shooter I've played on Steam. The squad can receive orders via keys, or accept them from your microphone. And since the squad isn't very good at following orders, you can drop the F-Bomb on them (the game actually recognizes a few curse words), and that makes for a good laugh when they respond back. Multiplayer is just horde mode, or verses, not much going on there.

A fun campaign with just over 11 hours of play. Worth a buy on a Steam sale.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Good shooter with a good story and awesome boss fights, worth playing and still good looking.

In a not too distant future, science allows to build robots which can be so humanlike, that you can't tell the difference from a normal human. To make it worse: robots have appeared which believe to be human themselves, and you are send to investigate the origin of these robots after one of them ran amok in the USA. Welcome to Japan, where the most advanced robot producing company produces their 'products'.

Binary domain starts as one of the usual third person shooters with covers announcing everywhere you'll get to find the enemy. As usual, you have a main weapon and you can pick up secondary weapons according to the situation. The enemies are robots with guns in different sizes and with different equipment like bulletproof shields or jetpacks. You play in a team with other soldiers with everyone having their own traits and even a personality shown in cutszenes and during the game. Something uncommon is also that you can upgrade your weapon, making it from a below average gun to your favourite tool to turn off enemies. Exactly, you are going to fight robots only except a few rare cases.

Another special feature this game has are decisionsyou have to make, and your teammates react to your decisions. they fight better if you support them, but they will fight less good and even reject orders if you ignore them. Usually this is not a big concern if you fight well.

Last but not least, let me mention the biggest enemies. I don't mean big, I mean BIG bossfights. Occasionally, you will encounter robots as large as small houses with each one require special tactics to beat them. They are challenging and fun to master. Does anyone here remember the last bossfight of Mass Effect 2?

So sum it up, Binary Domain is a well done third person shooter available for a more than reasonable price which offers 10 hours of gameplay.

reviewText:
This game is in my top 10 Third Person Shooter games of all time.  Most everything of this game is unique!  The Story line is unique the enemies are unique, the weapons are unique, and even the characters are unique!  Not only are they different, but they are emotionally amazing to watch!  When I played the game I got really attached to my comrades, especially the ones I always team up on.  And when they almost die, it is like a stab in the heart for me.  I never have been so attached to an NPC in my life, other than Mass Effect Series.  This game is amazing beyond compare, and I do not realize why it has such a low metascore it deserves at least an 80 or higher in my standards.  The one other thing that caught my eye is the mass number of different kind of robots that are in the game, sure there are the average Green Foot Soldiers but they account for the mass horde that attacks you!  It is just an amazing feeling to go up to an enemy Scrap Head and mash it to pieces with the butt of your rifle and watch it fall apart!  I must say the Graphics are amazing, and the physics are just as great!

Anyone looking for long, hard, and enjoyable story needs to check out this game!

reviewText:
I'll break my review down into chunks

Gameplay:
The gameplay while it can get repetative the sheer fact that you can dismantly your robotic enemies to hinder their fighting capability or destroy their armor to expose weakpoints like destroying the head so it starts shooting other robots. Another great thing is the boss fights while they can be your typical generic fights they still prove to be a good challenge. The game also throws in some RPG elements like upgrading weapons although sadly its only for primary weapons and not for your secondary or pistol and there is also skill augments to boost health and such. Last but not least the AI for the game works well although and responds well to the command system although its not recommended to use voice commands since its very buggy.

Story:
The story starts off kind of well and slows down a bit but around chapter 3 it really starts to pick up and near the end it has some really good bud mind♥♥♥♥ing twists to it that will leave you hungering for SEGA to hurry up and make a sequel.

Characters:
All of the characters have great voice actors and are very well animated with my favorite being Cain that is an android halfway through the game.

Graphics:
The graphics overall are very well done although nothing that will push the capabilities of any machine so most people can run it on high settings with no problem. Its to be noted the game has a 30 FPS cap set on it because this is a really bad PC port so they didnt do the simple task of taking off the limit but like many PC games simply modding/adding a file can remove the FPS restriction to provide smoother animations and such.

Sound:
Truthfully I didn't notice the music too much because I was so focused on blowing the robots to bits but the sound effects are well done.

Bugs:
Camera bug - The game has no bugs to speak of although once or twice I had a camera bug which is no big deal because the game uses checkpoint autosaves almost every 100ft or so on the levels making it easy to restart from a checkpoint if you encounter this bug. So if you encounter it just restart from a checkpoint because its not that big of a deal to be honest.
Control prompt bug? - Can't really say if this is a bug since generally most ♥♥♥♥ PC ports of games have really badly optimized control schemes but the prompts in this game tell you M" to fire(left click)
recommended: and lastly to use the shock burst ability(hold down middle moust button) which is annoying at first but you can easily deal with it after you get used to it 1-2 chapters into the game."

reviewText:
If you like killing tons of robots with a gears of war mechanic then this is for you. Haven't played multiplayer cuz I heard it's terrible but campaign is really fun. most of the story concepts are derivative of movies and anime. headshots have more incentive than other games because they cause robots to attacks each other (unless you use the sniper rifle). voice control is horrible. I spent an hour on configuring the voice controls only to get 50/72ish words recognized. It's just better without. the voice controls/ interactive concept is only for affecting your squads loyalty (decides whether they follow your orders). Every time you shoot an ally by mistake you lose loyalty; which is really annoying considering they will roll/change cover even if it takes them right in your line of fire (very common). can be really humorous. the controls the game says to use are incorrect and also don't change when you use an xbox controller; it will say to click 'M' when it's really your mouse left-click. it starts and closes really quickly on my entry level pc. buy it on sale. I definitely got my $4 worth!

Also, you can't change graphics settings or controls from in-game. it has to be done via the game configuration (when you launch from steam). I have 2 monitors and it defaulted to the wrong monitor so make sure you check out the configurations when you start. There aren't many options for changing the quality beyond shadows, SSAO, and a few other things.

overall 7.5/10 buy it on sale for a good time

EDIT: you can't change sensitivity AT ALL regardless of whether you're using a mouse or xbox controller. I wanted to use a controller but the sensitivity was too high so I used a mouse instead.

reviewText: Great (yet slightly ridiculous) story, super fun gunplay and awesome characters. SEGA's Yakuza Studio did such a great job with this one. Devil's Details PC port runs beautifully, although not many good anti-aliasing options. I had to use SMAA Injector and downsampling (3040x1710 to 1080p) to get rid of the jaggies, but even at that resolution the game never dipped once under 60 fps. Amazingly well optimized! Too bad that Binary Domain kinda bombed, such an overlooked gem.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: I wasn't expecting much when I picked up Binary Domain, but it turned out to be a pretty solid cover-shooter. Graphics are decent, voice-acting is serviceable and the gameplay mechanics all work well (aside from using grenades, which require you to switch to them as a main weapon). The story isn't bad, although the poor writing definitely makes it appear a lot worse than it actually is, relying on some really cliched, cheesy interactions between characters. I've heard it's a bad port, having nearly unusable mouse+keyboard controls, but when using a 360 controller it functions exactly as the console version, so I'd recommend that route. If you like cover-shooters and see if for a few dollars, I'd recommend picking it up.

reviewText:
Surprisingly good third-person shooter that feels a bit like Alpha Protocol mixed with Gears of War.

Pros:
- Above-average story for the genre that features a multicultural team of soldiers.
- Every enemy can be dismembered in different ways and this will affect their ability to fight you.
- While fighting the robots it practically rains pieces of metal. Very satisfying.
- Mild RPG elements that allow you to upgrade your weapons and statistics.
- Bosses are huge and difficult to take down with tactics that involve more than your standard wait till it shows the weak-spot" kind.
- Different dialogue based on who is in your team.

Cons:
- Friendly AI is pretty dumb and will run out of cover
date: dance around the battlefield or refuse to leave areas with respawning enemies.\n- Trust system doesn't amount to much and is easy to max out as long as you always agree with your team-mates when they talk. I didn't notice any difference between a high and low trust level either.\n- Commands also don't seem to work very well
recommended: so I ended up ignoring them. In the few cases I tried to get my AI to regroup while they were stuck in a different AI they would tell "that won't work" or something like that.\n- The love-story that develops as you progress the game felt off to me
hoursPlayed: especially since it involved a character I never interacted with and never added to my party.\n- Cutscenes often froze on me for a few seconds."

reviewText:
I expected an average game, but what I got is awesome storytelling, humor and brilliantly executed squad based combat. I absolutely loved the plot, the futuristic setting brings up etchical questions that are slowly beginning to unfold in today's field of robotics and AI.

Trust me, even if you are an avid follower of technology news, there are still such unique almost sci-fi like plot twists that will make you think about, how robots will influence our society in the future.

I fully recommend this title, you may have to get used to operating in a squad, but with practice in becomes a solid enjoyable shooter.

8/10

Binary Domain is a game I honestly stopped playing out of frustration with its controls and the amount of enemies that can stagger and stun lock you, forcing cheap and frustrating deaths.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Good shooter with a good story and awesome boss fights, worth playing and still good looking.

In a not too distant future, science allows to build robots which can be so humanlike, that you can't tell the difference from a normal human. To make it worse: robots have appeared which believe to be human themselves, and you are send to investigate the origin of these robots after one of them ran amok in the USA. Welcome to Japan, where the most advanced robot producing company produces their 'products'.

Binary domain starts as one of the usual third person shooters with covers announcing everywhere you'll get to find the enemy. As usual, you have a main weapon and you can pick up secondary weapons according to the situation. The enemies are robots with guns in different sizes and with different equipment like bulletproof shields or jetpacks. You play in a team with other soldiers with everyone having their own traits and even a personality shown in cutszenes and during the game. Something uncommon is also that you can upgrade your weapon, making it from a below average gun to your favourite tool to turn off enemies. Exactly, you are going to fight robots only except a few rare cases.

Another special feature this game has are decisionsyou have to make, and your teammates react to your decisions. they fight better if you support them, but they will fight less good and even reject orders if you ignore them. Usually this is not a big concern if you fight well.

Last but not least, let me mention the biggest enemies. I don't mean big, I mean BIG bossfights. Occasionally, you will encounter robots as large as small houses with each one require special tactics to beat them. They are challenging and fun to master. Does anyone here remember the last bossfight of Mass Effect 2?

So sum it up, Binary Domain is a well done third person shooter available for a more than reasonable price which offers 10 hours of gameplay.

reviewText:
A flawed but highly underrated game.
Combat is good though for a fluid experience you'll need to finetune your settings somewhat.
Voice commands work reasonably well but it'll take a bit to put in the correct sound orders.
In the end you just need: yes, no, fire and blitz. Try adding affirmative and negative too as alternatives.
Its useful in the interactions and in combat.

The strong point is the awesome team relation system and an excellent storyline that once it picks up pace vibrates with a veritable Asimov/cyberpunk/scifi anime (Spriggan, Patlabor,...) vibe.
A realistic setting where robots and moral choices regarding the creation of life, AI's etc are a key component of the plot.
And a cast that turns out far less stereotypical and one dimensional than one might think, once the game picks up pace and the plot develops.

reviewText:
Binary Domain is one of those games that slipped under the radar when it was released. Sega do occasionally make some very good games and this has the potential to be one of them.

It's a 3rd person shooter with team based mechanics, giving orders and building a relationship with your team AI is one of the main focus points of this game. The relationships will affect dialogue and also how they respond/help you during combat situations.
The voice acting is pretty poor but it adds a kind of comedy element to the story. The gameplay itself is pretty solid. The movement can feel a tad heavy at times but the shooting mechanics make up for it. The guns have good feedback and hit recognition which makes the limb mechanics that much better. The enemies you'll  be fighting are robots and you can shoot off body parts which all affect how they react/move during gameplay.

If you can grab this game cheap you won't be dissapointed

BINARY DOMAIN - 7.5 / 10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: It is a surprise that a game like this received such mixed ratings and is under the radar even today. I remember looking at a gameplay trailer for this game back in 2011 and was psyched, but other games went ahead to suck me in and I totally forgot about Binary Domain until I got it recently through the Humble Bundle sale. Needless to say I am very disappointed that I did not play such a great game when it came out, and I would not mind playing it again.\n\nBinary Domain is an amazing TPS in which its strong point lies within the story. Set in a 2080 version of Japan, Dan Marshall and his crew are sent in to take down a robotic threat. The story digs deep into the game, explaining the threat that is happening in Japan in a unique fashion. Many rising actions, plot twists, and more can keep you on your toes and be ready for more excitement. The characters in the game are worth noting too especially with the trust level system where you can increase the faith that your comrades have on you by doing certain actions. More trust in certain characters increases the likelihood that they will listen to your commands, another facet of the game. While commanding your allies is interesting, the big letdown of this feature is the voice recognition system which fails to work from time to time. Even then, there aren't enough commands to allow you to be a true squad leader, and sometimes the AI doesn't seem to follow your orders correctly despite having a lot of trust. The combat is your typical TPS gameplay mixed in with enemy robots that can lose their arm and still be able to fight. While the fighting is generic, you can mix up your play style through the usage of commands and the destuctible robots. And to top it all off, there are bosses that are mostly well designed and tough to beat. The soundtrack is great, but it doesn't seem to be played enough in game. While the cinematics are amazing, the voice acting could use a bit of work. Overall, Binary Domain is a solid TPS with a astounding storyline that will get you to play more.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'll break my review down into chunks

Gameplay:
The gameplay while it can get repetative the sheer fact that you can dismantly your robotic enemies to hinder their fighting capability or destroy their armor to expose weakpoints like destroying the head so it starts shooting other robots. Another great thing is the boss fights while they can be your typical generic fights they still prove to be a good challenge. The game also throws in some RPG elements like upgrading weapons although sadly its only for primary weapons and not for your secondary or pistol and there is also skill augments to boost health and such. Last but not least the AI for the game works well although and responds well to the command system although its not recommended to use voice commands since its very buggy.

Story:
The story starts off kind of well and slows down a bit but around chapter 3 it really starts to pick up and near the end it has some really good bud mind♥♥♥♥ing twists to it that will leave you hungering for SEGA to hurry up and make a sequel.

Characters:
All of the characters have great voice actors and are very well animated with my favorite being Cain that is an android halfway through the game.

Graphics:
The graphics overall are very well done although nothing that will push the capabilities of any machine so most people can run it on high settings with no problem. Its to be noted the game has a 30 FPS cap set on it because this is a really bad PC port so they didnt do the simple task of taking off the limit but like many PC games simply modding/adding a file can remove the FPS restriction to provide smoother animations and such.

Sound:
Truthfully I didn't notice the music too much because I was so focused on blowing the robots to bits but the sound effects are well done.

Bugs:
Camera bug - The game has no bugs to speak of although once or twice I had a camera bug which is no big deal because the game uses checkpoint autosaves almost every 100ft or so on the levels making it easy to restart from a checkpoint if you encounter this bug. So if you encounter it just restart from a checkpoint because its not that big of a deal to be honest.
Control prompt bug? - Can't really say if this is a bug since generally most ♥♥♥♥ PC ports of games have really badly optimized control schemes but the prompts in this game tell you M" to fire(left click)
recommended: and lastly to use the shock burst ability(hold down middle moust button) which is annoying at first but you can easily deal with it after you get used to it 1-2 chapters into the game."

reviewText: I wasn't expecting much when I picked up Binary Domain, but it turned out to be a pretty solid cover-shooter. Graphics are decent, voice-acting is serviceable and the gameplay mechanics all work well (aside from using grenades, which require you to switch to them as a main weapon). The story isn't bad, although the poor writing definitely makes it appear a lot worse than it actually is, relying on some really cliched, cheesy interactions between characters. I've heard it's a bad port, having nearly unusable mouse+keyboard controls, but when using a 360 controller it functions exactly as the console version, so I'd recommend that route. If you like cover-shooters and see if for a few dollars, I'd recommend picking it up.

reviewText:
A fun action packed futuristic Third Person shooter that rarely steps on the breaks!

Excellent Story, great characters that can take a liking or a hatred towards you depending on your decisions and actions.

Destroying robots is oh so satisfying in the many ways you can take em apart! (shooting off the head of a robot may cause it to shoot it's own allies LOL )

There's several weapons to equip and upgrade and as well upgrading your main character and your teammates with Nanomachine upgrades to enhance your team to it's fullest.

The game does have a voice recognition system but I never really used it but when I do use it. I do have some issues from it like, picking up things I'm not saying or not understanding me whatsoever.

You'll get around 12 hours of playtime from the main campaign and online multiplayer is somewhat dead but if  you do get into a match, expect some fun! (invite your friends or ask the forums!)

I highly recommend this title for TPS fans! Don't miss out on this! Also runs pretty well on a decent laptop.

The year is 2080. a lot happened. We play a character named Dan the survivor" who is part of a small elite goup called Rust Crew which is in charge of eliminating the robot enemies with covert operations around the world. This time

reviewText:
Good single-player campaign.  It has elements of a number of sci-fi stories in it, but I can't name them without spoiling the story.

The good:
Well-written campaign
Balanced difficulty
Invasion mode is very intense; hard, but challenging, not frustrating.

The meh:
The cover system used in the game is pretty flawed.  It's more to your benefit to stand up and creep around corners rather than get into cover.

The bad:
The ally AI is programmed to get in your line of fire.  Of course, it's YOUR fault if they get hit as a result.
The in-game voice system is useless.  Turning it off makes responding to in-game conversations easier.
The competitive multiplayer is boring.  It offers nothing you haven't seen with a better implementation.  The challenges you have to complete (for 100% completionists) are busywork.

reviewText:
This game is....

Actually really good.

No I'm serious, like there are a few dumb things about it but really the dialogue is well written, the plot is a little simple but it doesn't have any super obvious flaws (other than I guess the guessing game that is 'who on earth could be a hollow child'), the setting is presented well, graphics are not amazing but don't draw any complaints, and the controls are a little silly (the mouse is super sensitive by default, which is like the minimum setting) but honestly other than the mouse sensitivity thing that's my biggest gripe. Like the controls are solid, I think the characters are really amusing and what I'm doing all the time is actually pretty cool, which is to say dismantling robots with a perfectly good firearm.

What I am saying, gaming community, is that I like a game that I was probably the target audience of. Stop the presses, holy ♥♥♥♥, wow, what the hell is this.

There is one gripe, one, one huge gripe, and that is that the voice control thing is a pile of garbage. Thankfully that is just as easily replaced by a few simple button presses and, even though it's basically useless, is no reason to overlook this game. Yeah one gimmick didn't work but like, thirty others did. Like seriously, the tiny details in this game that make it more entertianing is the kind of stuff that should be taught in future game design.

So, yeah, sign me up for future rust crew action any time, this game is awesome.

Addendum:

Just beat this thing.... Devil's Details is better at action movies than Capcom.

Also, the quicktimes are the most infuriating thing I've ever seen but compared to a lot of big name devs they were practically sparse. Get rid of them entirely and this is maybe a perfect action third person shooter. Like, I shot lots of things, the controls worked pretty well, I actually kind of liked the characters most of the way through (that is to say 'thought they were well written' rather than 'thought they were good people') and I would honestly be up for the next Binary Domain if there is one.

Seriously, get this and play through it, it's amazing.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game had poor Keyboard & Mouse controls, inaccurate mic inputs and annoying teammate AI. That being said, it is one of the few games in recent memory I played from start to finish with almost no break.

The characters and the story are the main features that kept me invested in this game. The story wasn't anything mind blowing, but it was extremely enjoyable. The gameplay wasn't the greatest for me due to the poor K&M controls, but it didn't stop me from wanting to see what happens next. Facial expressions and voice acting in cutscenes are excellent(main characters voice is Mustang from Full Metal Alchemist). That being said, in combat the voice acting can be irritating with teammates spewing the same 3 lines. Again, a very minor issue. If you are the type of person that can overlook these small problems, you will be in for a treat.

Finishing this game left me wanting more, not unlike the ending of a good book or manga. If you can pick this up on special, don't hesitate. I wouldn't be mad if I bought this game at full price.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Good, but sometimes rough around the edges. Pick it up at a sale for ~10 hours of great shooting sprinkled with uneven but often suprisingly good writing.

I had a surprisingly good time with this game, it blends western and japanese design trends to great effect. It is a bit rough and choppy, and it is obvious that the development was cut short by publisher demands, but for what it is its a damn decent game.

The basic gameplay of shooting robots is really solid, and most of the boss fights were a great time. For a 3PS cover-shooter the combat is very mobile and dynamic.

What surprised me most was the quality of the writing and acting: Its not perfect, and cliché at times, but it brings some real emotion and tackles some pretty high-concept sci-fi themes. For better or worse it tells its story in a very Japanese" way: philosophical themes and strong emotions
date: though often heavy handed and with a distinct lack of player choice."

reviewText:
Graphics: The reason I decided to get this game was because I am a MASSIVE fan of the (sadly PlayStation exclusive) Yakuza franchise which was created by the same person as this and developed at the same Sega-owned studio using the same game engine. And WOW, the difference between the two platforms is absolutely remarkable. This game runs at 60FPS virtually all the time on my PC, the field of view is adjustable for both running and aiming and is set nice and high by default so you've got a good view all around you, and all of the menus and HUDs and everything just look really modern and smooth. This is in stark contrats to Yakuza, which just looks clunky and outdated by comparison, not to mention the woeful FPS, which can sometimes cause actual slowdowns like you'd get on an emulator if they decide to add in particle effects. All this on a game engine that was DESIGNED for Playstation exclusivity! I suppose I'm being a bit unfair, as 3rd person linear shooters like this are always going to use up less resources than an open-world game like Yakuza, but it just goes to show why people like PC gaming so much. I mean, sure, good graphics don't make a good game, but it's certainly a nice thing to have as far as I'm concerned.
Story: This is where things get interesting. You're actually running on a consequence-based system, so what eventually happens to the characters (including whether some of them live to see the end of the game) depends on how much trust you build up with them during gameplay (more on this in a bit). I won't bore you with a story synopsis since you can just get that off the store page or Wikipedia, but personally, I liked the way it unfolded. It's got a few nice twists and turns here and there and whilst it's not the most amazing or unpredictable story you'll ever experience, it's certainly a damn sight better than your average Call of Duty game.
Gameplay: If you're used to battle games, this one won't be a problem as far as the mechanics of the shooting, taking cover, that sort of thing are concerned. The only issue I had was that the game was very sensitive to mouse inputs, but if you've got a mouse with variable sensitivity, just turn it down and it's not much of an issue. The enemy AI is pretty good, and you really have to move around between bits of cover to avoid them busting you out, making for a challenging shooting game. The most annoying issue of this whole game is the fact that they developed it with voice input in mind. In theory, it allows you to give orders to your characters, as well as answering questions that will raise their trust level with you if you answer correctly. This can be pretty annoying during battles if you don't want to use the voice input system or you don't have a microphone, because you have to hold down the capslock key and select your answer using another key, all while your character is basically disabled. Not exactly ideal at all if you're trying to shoot at robots and whatnot. The trust system can be quite annoying during gameplay as well. If your character becomes too badly injured, they will have to heal themselves with a health kit, or be healed by one of their team mates. If you refuse to be healed by someone, that person's trust in you will decrease. These are the most annoying issues of the game, and if you can live with them it's fine. You also gain increased trust for being good at shooting, getting a lot of headshots and whatnot, so this is a good game for people who are good shooters.
Although you always play as Dan on this game, you do have a choice as to what people (or robots) you want in your battle team for particular sections of the story. Each character carries their own type of weapon, meaning that you have to be careful with character selection. There is also the chance of upgrading both weapons and character abilites by spending money earned for defeating bad guys.
Audio: This is probably the weakest point of the game. I think the gun sound effects are pretty weak if I'm honest, but what I really don't like is the voice acting. I mean, given that most of Ryuu Ga Gotoku studio's games are only dubbed in Japanese, I think having a game dubbed not just in Japanese and English, but SIX languages was always going to be ambitious to say the least. I get the feeling that Sega simply contracted out the voice work to some American studio who had little to no idea of what foreign people actually sound like. I mean, it's not as if they skimped on the voice talent, with both Laura Bailey and Troy Baker having roles (I'm starting to think these two are some kind of prerequesite for including in an English dubbed videogame these days...) And I must say that Baker's British accent as Charlie is pretty good, but Bailey's performance as Faye Lee is pretty awful. She sounds more like someone from Mexico than China. Normally she's a fantastic voice actress, but I think foreign accents are clearly her weak point. The woman who did Rachel's voice was by far the worst though. She had the same sort of cringeworthily fake British" accent that you'd expect to hear on an episode of The Simpsons. Not to mention she couldn't even say "Yakuza" properly. Some characters didn't even bother with trying to put on an accent
date: one little girl in the slums speaking English in a perfect American accent. Overall
recommended: the cringeworthy foreign accents really ruined the story for me
hoursPlayed: giving you the impression of some low-budget B-movie
voteText: rather than the sci-fi epic it was clearly supposed to be. It's not all bad though; Dan's got a Harrison Ford-like voice which fits his character very well
helpfulPercent: and Boateng's voice fits the "token black guy" character pretty well as well. But then again
votesHelpful: people who can do those sorts of voices are ten a penny in the voice acting world
votesTotal: so it's hardly a massive surprise.\n\nOverall impression: Cultural ignorance aside
votesFunny: I do really like this game. It's fantastic for anyone who likes 3rd person shooters as well as futuristic sci-fi types of games like Crysis. And of course
commentsCount: this game is a must for any Yakuza fan. Recommended."

reviewText:
Good single-player campaign.  It has elements of a number of sci-fi stories in it, but I can't name them without spoiling the story.

The good:
Well-written campaign
Balanced difficulty
Invasion mode is very intense; hard, but challenging, not frustrating.

The meh:
The cover system used in the game is pretty flawed.  It's more to your benefit to stand up and creep around corners rather than get into cover.

The bad:
The ally AI is programmed to get in your line of fire.  Of course, it's YOUR fault if they get hit as a result.
The in-game voice system is useless.  Turning it off makes responding to in-game conversations easier.
The competitive multiplayer is boring.  It offers nothing you haven't seen with a better implementation.  The challenges you have to complete (for 100% completionists) are busywork.

reviewText:
This game had poor Keyboard & Mouse controls, inaccurate mic inputs and annoying teammate AI. That being said, it is one of the few games in recent memory I played from start to finish with almost no break.

The characters and the story are the main features that kept me invested in this game. The story wasn't anything mind blowing, but it was extremely enjoyable. The gameplay wasn't the greatest for me due to the poor K&M controls, but it didn't stop me from wanting to see what happens next. Facial expressions and voice acting in cutscenes are excellent(main characters voice is Mustang from Full Metal Alchemist). That being said, in combat the voice acting can be irritating with teammates spewing the same 3 lines. Again, a very minor issue. If you are the type of person that can overlook these small problems, you will be in for a treat.

Finishing this game left me wanting more, not unlike the ending of a good book or manga. If you can pick this up on special, don't hesitate. I wouldn't be mad if I bought this game at full price.

reviewText:
This game is....

Actually really good.

No I'm serious, like there are a few dumb things about it but really the dialogue is well written, the plot is a little simple but it doesn't have any super obvious flaws (other than I guess the guessing game that is 'who on earth could be a hollow child'), the setting is presented well, graphics are not amazing but don't draw any complaints, and the controls are a little silly (the mouse is super sensitive by default, which is like the minimum setting) but honestly other than the mouse sensitivity thing that's my biggest gripe. Like the controls are solid, I think the characters are really amusing and what I'm doing all the time is actually pretty cool, which is to say dismantling robots with a perfectly good firearm.

What I am saying, gaming community, is that I like a game that I was probably the target audience of. Stop the presses, holy ♥♥♥♥, wow, what the hell is this.

There is one gripe, one, one huge gripe, and that is that the voice control thing is a pile of garbage. Thankfully that is just as easily replaced by a few simple button presses and, even though it's basically useless, is no reason to overlook this game. Yeah one gimmick didn't work but like, thirty others did. Like seriously, the tiny details in this game that make it more entertianing is the kind of stuff that should be taught in future game design.

So, yeah, sign me up for future rust crew action any time, this game is awesome.

Addendum:

Just beat this thing.... Devil's Details is better at action movies than Capcom.

Also, the quicktimes are the most infuriating thing I've ever seen but compared to a lot of big name devs they were practically sparse. Get rid of them entirely and this is maybe a perfect action third person shooter. Like, I shot lots of things, the controls worked pretty well, I actually kind of liked the characters most of the way through (that is to say 'thought they were well written' rather than 'thought they were good people') and I would honestly be up for the next Binary Domain if there is one.

Seriously, get this and play through it, it's amazing.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Note: I recieved this product for free as part of the SEGA Make War Not Love promotion.

Binary Domain is a Sci-Fi RPG/Third-Person Shooter occurring in near-future Japan.  You play as Dan Marshall, generic white action hero, as you discover the truth behind events which violate the New Geneva Convention.  Since I don't write long reviews, I'll use a pro/con format.

Pros:
-Good cover mechanics.
-Enemies fall apart as you shoot them, and will crawl to you if you shoot their legs off, or will shoot allies if you get a headshot.
-Graphics are nice, considering the release date of the game.
-Runs on an i3 with HD 3000 graphics.
-Story is very Blade Runner.

Cons:
-Not a whole lot of variety of guns.
-I have the collapsing bridge bug, had a friend play past that.
-Is rather repetitive after a while since you're shooting robots, although said robots use cover and try to flank you.
-I personally hate Quick-Time Events

reviewText:
I had played the demo of this a while ago, and felt then that it had decent, if generic, third person cover-based shooter gameplay and a weird voice-activated squad command system that I didn't expect to use.

Turns out that that was a completely correct assessment that nevertheless managed to completely miss the point.

Binary Domain tells the story of a covert task force sent into Japan to investigate the source of Hollow Children, robots indistinguishable from humans that actually believe that they are human until they are activated. The perfect sleeper agents, who have been popping up across the world recently.
All clues point to a mysterious robotics company, led by a director that hasn't been seen in public in decades.

If that feels generic then you would be correct, the game hits a bunch of tropes over the course of its ~15 hour campaign.
In much the same vein your team doesn't consist of international characters, but rather of international stereotypes.

The arrogant American, the bro-tastic African American, the sarcastic Brit, the smooth French one, the stoic Chinese one.
Players are unfortunately locked in as the arrogant American, but are free to choose which characters they bring on missions (up to two, only ones they've already encountered) which covers roles of the team that you don't want to take care of yourself.
Don't feel like sniping? Bring the sniper. Prefer sniping instead? Leave her home and bring an assault character instead that will draw fire as you pick off enemy robots from a distance.

Yep, robots. All opposition you'll face, except for some very few exceptions, will be robotic creations of the robotics conglomerate. This might sound boring, but it allows for some very nice destruction systems where you can disable parts of your opponents, changing their behaviours. The generic humanoid variants will crawl around if you shoot off their legs and will start shooting their allies instead of you if you manage to shoot their heads off.

Your squad mates will comment on everything you do, from yelling out requests for assistance to compliments on successful takedowns to talking about recent plot developments. You are able to respond to these, theoretically by using voice commands but for the people that couldn't be bothered (like me) there are also keyboard / controller responses available. They way you interact with your squad mates will raise or lower their opinion of you which does... something.

I've only completed one playthrough, so I'm not quite sure what things could all have gone differently, but I feel that some squad members coming to my rescue and a romance subplot were optional things that I managed to trigger by which squad members I favoured.
This means that my opinion of the ending that I got might be completely irrelevant to your potential playthrough, but I REALLY liked the ending.

In fact, my opinion of the game almost consistently got higher and higher from its slightly shaky start.
Everything slowly ramps up until an admittedly very... classic, quite predictable final boss fight that I felt was very satisfying (and, as it should be, it is definitely the hardest fight in the game, at least it was for me).

If you feel like playing a fun, highly playable action game with some clever twists and turns that gets better if you stick with it, definitely give Binary Domain a try.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Every now and then, you play a game that appears to be a generic third person shooter. But under its covers is a great game that isn't so generic, primarily because it doesn't take itself seriously at all. Binary Domain is one of those games. It has a somewhat generic plot of an evil executive/inventor who uses their robots to cause havoc and is creating an experiment that the US government isn't fond of, so the US government and the Geneva convention send in a Rust Crew to uncover the conspiracy. Yeah, it sounds pretty generic. But it's an absolute blast to play. There's a reason why some over-the-top third person shooters are so popular, it's because they're so much fun!

What I also like about Binary Domain is the setting, the sprawling metropolis of Tokyo. And the main characters, their banter and wit makes the game so much more enjoyable and a bit light hearted instead of other third person shooters that take themselves too seriously. Binary Domain also utilizes a unique consequence system, where certain actions will either raise or lower the trust of your comrades. Dan Marshall, the character you play, runs into a number of people as your crew grows throughout the course of the game. Your actions can slightly effect the end of the game.

Overall, it's just a ridiculous action game with a pretty good story, but really great characters that you'll grow to love. Smooth gameplay too. It's, by no means, a masterpiece, but definitely a great game.

8.5/10

reviewText:
Single Player Campaign review only.

Binary Domain is a 3rd-person tactical shooter (like Gears of War) in a cyberpunk setting. Dan Marshall & his crew are to clean-up the mess a corporation made, creating robots that look & act like humans.

The action, shooting & destruction of robots is just pure bliss, as enemies can be destroyed to pieces & will keep coming at you 'til they're completely destroyed (like in Dead Space)! Boss fights are awesome - though, there are a few that are tough.

The characters, voice-acting, writing & dialogue are good. The premise & plot itself is pretty good, better than the writing. You give orders to your party members, via selecting dialogue options on your gamepad or keyboard/mouse - or even w/ the mic, since the game has voice-recognition & recognizes numerous phrases you say. Well, it tries to, at least. You're better off using dialogue options via KB/mouse or gamepad.

Simply put - BD is an awesome shooter & easy to reccommend.

SP Campaign -- Grade = B+

The story plot was quite nice, with a few twists, and the graphics are fine ; but more important, this game is extremely fun to play.
The cover system is very well implemented, and it's really enjoyable to tear hordes of robots into parts (very good & visible damage localisation). There are lots of interresting bosses fights to handle, to boot.

At the price it can be found now, you should do yourself a favor, and buy this game!

reviewText:
Binary Domain was a suprisingly a quite good game. The shooting mechanics are like any other standard 3rd person cover based shooter. But this game is still fun to play and tries some new things; such as a trust system with your party members that can be altered based on your responses and your actions in combat that ultimately affect the games ending. I should note that the robots also have some very nice destruction physics.

This game initally had a few port issues, such as mouse acceleration and performance issue's but they seem to have been fixed now as I played through it without problems.

The main draw for me though was the plot, the game is set in a futuristic world where robotic technology has become very advanced, some would say a little too advanced, I do not want to spoil anything but it covers the themes of morality, life and evolution. Although a lot of the characters are cliche the voice acting is very good and the storyline was very interesting and unique, it certainly left me thinking for a while afterwards.

Oh and you probably shouldn't buy this if you are intrested in the multiplayer unless you have some friends to play with as it seemed to have been Dead On Arrival.

reviewText:
A great sci-fi, squad-based shooter that is criminally under-appreciated.

Can the japanese make good shooters? Binary Domain proves they can.

Combining an intiguing plot with some chraming and humorous dialogue, levels which for the most part allow space to move around and enemies which are not afraid to come up close and personal, Binary Domain makes for an intense and enjoyable experience.

1st thing that is different about the game from most modern shooters : your teamates are actually useful. They will heal you when your down, they actually takedown their fair share of enemies (prventing you from getting swamped) and you can give them rudimentary commands or even make small talk with them.

Another difference is the enemies do not go down in a few hits, neither are they the typical bullet sponges. You can blow off their legs, they will come crawling after you, grabbing your legs if they get too close. BLow off their heads and they may start attacking their own side, blow off one arm, they will use the other to hit you. The sight of armor plating getting blown off and shattering into pieces gives the weapons a sense of impact and great satisfaction.

Fov can be adjusted and mouse acceleration is acceptable (for me at least).

Graphics can be subpar, especially close up, with some very low res textures.

Performance is great, smooth 60fps even in intense firefights.

Advise you to download the demo, at least give it a shot.

reviewText:
Voice commands are a neat gimmic, but they don't work here. Random commands and poor recognition soon made me turn the feature off. Even with this mechanic them out of the equasoion, and Binary Domain is still a stellar and largly overlooked title.
The writing won't blow you away, the charicters are all cliche, and the story has been done to death before, but all three of these elements are still executed novely enough to more than simply keep you interested. In a nutshell, the game is Terminator action in the Bladerunner world, with Gears of War gameplay.  What makes this title stand out the most though is an aspect of shooter games that often goes overlooked: the impact that your shots make on your enemies.
In a world overpopulated by zombie shooters, robots seem like a brave choise for a new ip. I think one of the main reasons people like zombies is that they splat rather well. Sega took this cue and actually made robots VISCERAL, and not in an Ash from Alien kind of way. The fantastic maner in which scrap metal is shead when these bots are shot makes combat a real charm. More games could learn from Sega's direction here.
The imact of bullets is somthing that rarely seems to get attention in games. It is for this reason that the origional Hous of the Dead remains a favorite. Sega really knows how to make 'em fall apart right! Somthing  that The House of the Dead got right that this game has failed horribly at is having a decent cover. The Binary Domain cover couldn't have looked more generic if it actually tried to.

Le Robot out of Ten

reviewText:
Binary Domain suprised me.

There's not a lot of games that managed to do that- after a rather boring and generic intro level (some 10 minutes of it) I was already starting to regret buying it, and ready to write it off as yet another generic cover based shooter.

Then came the intro. And I was sitting up in my chair, getting very interested in the drama all of a sudden. It was GOOD. The plot was intriguing, the characters actually had personalities, the voice acting was top notch, and they got actual Japanese voice actors to play Japanese characters, which is both a big bonus in my book, and makes the game feel anime-like a LOT.

The cutscenes are pretty much what makes this game good, like with Metal Gear Solid series. There's plenty of them, they have excellent direction and they have managed to get me hooked on the story, and even make me laugh out loud a few times!

If you're into futuristic robot-themed anime-like stuff, I can definitely recommend this game. It getting rather cheap on sales is also added incentive for getting it.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I thoroughly enjoyed this game and recommend it to all those who like a nice single-player campaing with a captivating story. I just finished it and loved it.
The story is creative and very good, with a good emotional element too which adds a nice touch. You truly bond with your teammates and the girl of course. It's the kind of story which motivates me to keep going until the finish... just like a good book.
The combat mechanics are very enjoyable.. made me feel as if I'm really fighting, not just shooting or pressing button combinations. The physics and robot destruction are very enjoyable and satisfying too.

Full of action, story elements, emotional team engagement, and great gameplay.
Highly recommended.

reviewText:
My Binary Domain Impressions

Story:
In the future mankind couldn't stop global warming which lead to catastrophic rises in sea levels. Huge landmasses have been flooded and many died. Gigantic walls were built to fend off the oceans. Only robots could achieve this colossal task. Having proven themselves robots are now present everywhere in society. This led two corporations to huge success, the American Bergen and Japanese Amada.
As a result politicians have put restrictive laws into R&D of life-like robots indistinguishable from humans, Hollow Children". You play as a member of a RUST crew whose job it is to go after violations against these laws.
When a Hollow Child not even knowing it is non-human is found
date:
you and a multinational team are sent covertly to Japan to find evidence against the Amada corporation.

Gameplay:
Binary Domain is a fairly standard third-person-shooter with many inventive systems. Each of your crew members has a "trust meter". This will either fill or decrease upon your choices during dialogue and whether you protect them during combat. Another neat idea is the implementation of voice-enabled commands. I didn't use a mic so I had to use pre-config commands via button press. These can go from combat orders like "Give me cover fire" up to opinions on your crews mood and comments on events unfolding in the story.

As a TPS shooting is the main focus. And boy does it shine. Movement is adequately quick with dedicated "dodge" moves. Weapon variety is standard with a nice selection of grenades. Experience points are used to upgrade your weapon and character stats. Don't expect anything too deep though. It is held enjoyably simple.
Your arsenal will get its fair share of use against the many robots you will be facing in the ~8 hour campaign. To my big surprise devs managed to turn a cliche enemy like robots into one of the most enjoyable adversaries in a long time. They are not stupid! They will take cover
hoursPlayed: dodge attacks and be formidable opponents. Prepare to take cover a lot as rushing into combat will get you killed fast. But keep calm as disposing robots is as fun as it can get. Bullets stagger them with very good hit animations while clusters of their outer shell is shred flying all around the screen. Good placed shoots will sever limbs
voteText: send legs and arms flying around. Don't loose your focus though as these robots will continue pursuing you even without any legs. Headshots will turn robots into shooting sprees hitting their robot brethren
helpfulPercent: so keep your aim steady! Combat is the shining beacon among all other greatness. From the clean and futuristic landscapes with huge scope to the many and frequent set pieces which never outstay their welcome. Speaking of
votesHelpful: levels are diverse while still retaining general tone of futuristic Tokyo. Each of them ends with a boss. Varying in fun while all of them can make quick business of you. Running from cover to cover
votesTotal:
commanding your teammates at the right moment and using appropriate weapons will make them a challenge but never unfair.

Verdict:
Not having heard much from Binary Domain previously the screenshots and game banner did paint a very mediocre image. I'm glad I still gave the game a try as it became one of my most beloved TPS of recent years. It's polished with good voice acting
votesFunny: making me care about my teammates. The theme of robots and trans-humanism are interesting and were nicely woven into the story. Unforeseen twists kept me at the edge of my seat and I genuinely cared about the events that unfold. A very satisfying game which I hope gets a sequel."

reviewText: Fabuła i scenariusz w Binary Domian przywodzą na myśl najlepsze japońskie bajki animowane. Jest wątek miłosny, trochę dramaturgii oraz cała masa świetnie zaprojektowanych przeciwników. reviewText:
Let me preface this by saying that I do not particularly like third person shooters.
The enemies are bullet sponges. Bosses involve hitting small moving targets (often while moving about yourself) while aiming in a narrowed field of vision and being unable to see attacks that will stagger, stunlock or OHK you. And that's pretty much everything wrong with the game.

The characters are brilliant, the banter between your squadmates makes them instantly lovable (though they will nag the hell out of you if you decide to go hunting for secrets), the level designs really give off the sort of air you expect from a near future society, mechanical designs are superb ranging from floating cameras to the sort of thing that will make you scream at your monitor How do you make something like this and not call yourself an evil genius!?" (true quote)
date: music and sound effects are solid even to the point of making sure that many of the Japanese you will encounter actually speak Japanese and their accents nail it when they speak English too. There will be scenes throughout the game that will make you question "Did that happen because I chose to take X with me?" and are executed flawlessly in line with the story. Which speaking of story
recommended: if you enjoy your cyberpunk stuff this has a bit of a typical subject matter but it is told exceedingly well.\n\nReally
hoursPlayed: this game is a hidden gem if ever there was one and for the price tag it's a crime against gaming not to at least give it a try. There's even a demo

reviewText:
Binary Domain starts out as an uninteresting shooter. Limited squad controls, useless speech commands and clumsy controls. The button mapping is the worst. They kept the merged keys, so usually there is one button for 2 or 3 actions which makes everything much worse. There are no graphics options, and almost no in-game options. As a port it is failed in so many ways.
The graphics are serviceable. Characters look good from a distance, but closeup the poor texture quality can be seen. Regular robot enemies are looking okay, they lose a lot of scrap before die, which looks great. There are some sequences where it is almost like a terminator game. Locations are okay, sometimes a little bit too strict. There are many good designs in terms of bosses, which are a lot of here. Also, there are too many special sequences in the game. Otherwise, boss fights can be interesting and rather frustrating either. This is a mixed bag.
The story itself is starting to get interesting after a few hours, but becomes quite a mess in the end. There are many cliched and cheesy scenes which are way out of track. The twists are pretty much foreseeable by anyone who used to watch movies. There is not much to say about it. In the 2/3 of the game there is a chance to select your teammates which will carry on with you. This adds some variety to the game. For example, I managed to select the robot with another one out of 5, then him out of 2 before a gas chamber room. He even said that he is not having a problem with the situation. There are various speech from squaddies during the missions which are spot on. They should had a lot of work with all the different dialogs.
There are some rpg" elements also. You can buy upgrades for your mates
date: earn their trust by agreeing with them and leveling up their weapons. The options are pretty slim
recommended: but at least there are some.\n\nOverall

reviewText:
ONE OF THE MOST UNDERRATED SHOOTERS OF ALL TIME - BUY AND PLAY IT

Yeah, that pretty much says it all.

But in case you need a little bit more, let me be a tad more precise. The game itself is fun. Remember when this was kinda important in games? Yeah, it is mostly some cover-based shooting, but it just feels good - the graphics, sounds, music, cheesy one.liners, shuffling through various weapons.. it is a bit like the classic 80s-90s action movies. So that's all kinda okay.

But...

..where the game really stands out is the story and the characters. The story may seem to be a little bit clich= at the beginning, but it develops very nicely and you WILL be interested in it (which is more than I can say about most of shooters), it even poses some quasi-philosophical questions! I loved it. Surprisingly, there is also some minor almost-rpg character upgrading and team management - you get to pick your mates (and improve your relationship with them that way, which makes impact on the story!! - show me any other shooter that does this) from a group of well-written individuals, each with a different combat style that can complete yours approach or mimick it (tank-like heavy gunner, shotgun shock trooper, sniper etc)!

Just..give it a shot. You won't be disappointed.
