reviewText: If you're a hardcore gamer of FPS, I don't suggest this game to you because the story is the best part of this game, not the action, compared to other similar games. I must say that the work of the screenwriters is absolutely outstanding, shocking me and moving me to my heart deeply.

reviewText:
Binary Domain... good or bad?

I'd say it is a fun FLAWED game and if you can get past the flaws, you can enjoy it!

PROS:
+FUN Big boss battles against challenging foes.
+Voice control support (great tech but only when it is working properly).
+Nice robot destruction effects.
+Decent graphics.
+Good music.
+Weapons upgrades.
+Augmentations for your gear.

CONS:
-HORRIBLE AND CHEESY VOICE ACTING!
-Story is somewhat decent but still cliché-ed (like a mix of many genres).
-Voice control support doesn't work well and register wrong spoken words mostly.
-Laughable dialog.
-Poor keyboard and mouse controls.
-Cardboard cutout characters.
-A.I. partners are quite worthless and very annoying!

OVERALL:
It is a Gears of War clone (yes yet another one!) with fun shooting (when it works) but sadly, it is filled with flaws that sometimes, makes the game quite frustrating. I haven't tried the online mode nor I am willing to spend time on it. I finished the game now its time to uninstall it!

At the end, it is hinted for a possible sequel but that depends whether the game made good financially or not.

RECOMMENDATION:
If you love Gears of War playstyle and seek a similar game, give it a spin... but please, do so when the game is on a sale!

RATING:
6 / 10

reviewText:
Total playtime on the hardest difficulty available at the start of the game (an additional difficulty unlocked after I beat the game the first time): 11 hours

This is an incredibly solid third-person shooter in a market that probably has too many and is definitely worth a playthrough. I got it on sale, but, after finishing it, I can definitely say I would have gladly paid the $15 it's currently priced at.

Technically this is a cover-based shooter, but even on the hardest difficulty setting initially available actually using the cover mechanics is usually a suggestion and not a requirement. That's a plus, in my book; I find being forced to take cover every single fight is annoying as hell. That's not to say you'll NEVER have to take cover (although perhaps you can get away with doing so on the easier difficulties), merely that in most of the fights I experienced it was not necessary. This becomes doubly true later on in the game when you've been upgrading your assault rifle to its max stats; once I hit level 5 or so in firepower (out of 6 or 7, I can't remember offhand) I never took cover again except for boss battles.

Gunplay is tight. The main character has an assault rifle and a backup pistol (the pistol has infinite ammo) with him at all times, and a third weapon slot that can be used to carry enemy weapons or other pick-ups. I can remember the following weapons: the enemy assault rifle, an SMG, a shotgun, two different kinds of sniper rifles, and an RPG. So the guns are definitely not unique, but they DO feel...good, for lack of a better description? I never felt like the weapons were weak or lacked kick like I do in some shooters. Enemies also react well to being shot; you can shoot off legs to force them to crawl, shoot off arms so they can't use weapons, and shoot off heads so they begin fighting against their own side.

One weapon feature worth mentioning is the main character's assault rifle's shock burst feature. It can be used to disable and knockback all of the robotic enemies (every single enemy is robotic except for one boss fight) and can be recharged from battery pickups the enemies drop. I didn't find myself using that often except against bosses; the range on the burst is fairly short compared to your normal rifle range and getting that close to a horde of enemies is a rather bad idea. On the topic of bosses, there are MANY of them, and most of them are fun to fight against (with the exception of the gorilla robot boss that you fight twice who is nothing but a gigantic pain in the ♥♥♥, and the transforming mech motorcycle which is nothing but an HP sink).

The game features an upgradable weapon system, not only for the main assault rifle but also for the weapons of your teammates. I'll go ahead and say that upgrading your allies' weapons is completely useless; you won't always be able to use your teammate of choice and most of their usefulness isn't in their firepower: it's in reviving you when you get downed and acting as a temporary decoy. The other upgrading system is the nanomachine system. Each character has a 2x3 grid on which to place dots (representing nanomachines) of various shapes. Most of them just increase health/defense/health regeneration/melee power, but there are exceptions, like Faye's nanomachines to increase her sniping accuracy. Several characters also have nanomachines that allow them to carry more revival medkits (I recommend these since, as I said, a large part of their usefulness is in reviving you when you get downed).

Now, about teammates...throughout most of the game you are allowed to create a squad of 3 characters (the main character + 2 teammates of your choice) from a selection of 4-5 teammates. Big Bo uses an assault rifle and is fairly tanky, Charlie uses an SMG, Rachael uses a shotgun and explosives, Faye uses a sniper rifle, and Cain uses a machine pistol and frequent melee (and is also, in my experience, the tankiest character). In battle you can give them orders, which they may or may not follow based on their current trust in you, which brings us to the trust system.

Characters in your party can gain or lose trust in you several ways. The most common way to gain trust is simply to do exceptionally well in battle; not only will they compliment you during the battle itself (and gain trust immediately), but it also creates a chance for them to open a dialogue with you after battle and gain even MORE trust. Several times throughout the 6 chapters characters will also stop you in hallways (or in other non-combat areas like elevators) and start a story-based dialogue there wherein they ask you questions. You can respond affirmatively/helpfully (almost always the correct" choice to gain trust) or negatively/sarcastically (which almost universally loses trust). Shooting teammates of course drops their trust in you (which is quite annoying when they run right in front of you as you're shooting)

reviewText: I originally gave this game a negative review because I ran into a QTE I couldn't pass, turns out my old computer was just sh*t and now I've beaten the game. First thing first though, you're going to need a controller to play it because the KB+M controls are bad.\n\nBinary Domain is a bit of a diamond in the rough, it’s like a cheesy action movie in all the best ways. The combat is fun, though some boss fights can be kind of b*llsh*t. The combat is really helped by how reactive the robots are to your shots, bullet sponges they are not. It’s really satisfying blowing off a robot’s legs or doing a headshot. The writing is delightfully goofy and the main cast are all likable because of this, like your best buddy Big Bo and the French robot Cain. The mic mechanic is janky as hell, so I’d suggest not using it. You don’t really need it that much anyway because you get loyalty points from your squadmates for just doing well in the game. Binary Domain is definitely worth your time and needs some more love.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is really fun! The combat (while derivative of other TPS) is solid, and the enemies, the 'robot-gore', and the environments are cool. The game also looks great, and the design is fantastic as well - the cityscape is wonderful to look at and really feels like a great blend of sci-fi futurism and gritty realism, and the character models are detailed and instantly recognisable. But the strongest feature of the game (in my opinion) are the cutscenes. The script is well written and the performances are pitch perfect and committed across the board. More importantly, I can follow the story and am invested in the characters, and I'm enjoying this more and more as it goes on.

I didn't realise that voice-recognition was such a big part of the game, and while it's gimmicky and can be frustrating at times, it is great fun at times to yell 'charge!' at one of your characters and have them respond to the command, throwing themselves into the enemy.

Everything that's great about it certainly makes up for any shortcomings in my opinion.

reviewText:
Do I recommend this game? Hell yes I do.

Plot - This game's plot is amazing. It's complex, but not to the point where it's convoluted. It's a very enjoyable ride full of twists and turns and one that will keep you thinking. If you're looking for a mindless shooter, this is it. If you're looking for a intriguing and thought-provoking shooter that raises questions of ethics, this is it as well. Stay after the credits! Characters are loveable (talk to them- they feed you small morsels of their background). Bonus points to this game for being genuinely funny! It cracks jokes and comments naturally through conversations; nothing feels forced.

Gameplay - This game truly revives the art of grandiose boss fights. Bosses appear frequently, are innovative and unique, appear and are menacing, and most importantly, they're pretty freaking huge. Many will make you go Holy [censored]!" The gunplay is very fun as well. Each body part of each enemy is destructable
date: and enemies will adapt to every predicament they're in. There's not a gigantic variety of guns
recommended: but you won't even notice; the moment you realize the plethora of ways to fight each battle
hoursPlayed: you will forget everything else. Assault? Sure. Snipe? Sure. Support? Sure. Turn enemies against each other? Why not? There's quite a bit of replay value here.\n\nSound - A superbly done pumping techno soundtrack. Sure

reviewText:
Total playtime on the hardest difficulty available at the start of the game (an additional difficulty unlocked after I beat the game the first time): 11 hours

This is an incredibly solid third-person shooter in a market that probably has too many and is definitely worth a playthrough. I got it on sale, but, after finishing it, I can definitely say I would have gladly paid the $15 it's currently priced at.

Technically this is a cover-based shooter, but even on the hardest difficulty setting initially available actually using the cover mechanics is usually a suggestion and not a requirement. That's a plus, in my book; I find being forced to take cover every single fight is annoying as hell. That's not to say you'll NEVER have to take cover (although perhaps you can get away with doing so on the easier difficulties), merely that in most of the fights I experienced it was not necessary. This becomes doubly true later on in the game when you've been upgrading your assault rifle to its max stats; once I hit level 5 or so in firepower (out of 6 or 7, I can't remember offhand) I never took cover again except for boss battles.

Gunplay is tight. The main character has an assault rifle and a backup pistol (the pistol has infinite ammo) with him at all times, and a third weapon slot that can be used to carry enemy weapons or other pick-ups. I can remember the following weapons: the enemy assault rifle, an SMG, a shotgun, two different kinds of sniper rifles, and an RPG. So the guns are definitely not unique, but they DO feel...good, for lack of a better description? I never felt like the weapons were weak or lacked kick like I do in some shooters. Enemies also react well to being shot; you can shoot off legs to force them to crawl, shoot off arms so they can't use weapons, and shoot off heads so they begin fighting against their own side.

One weapon feature worth mentioning is the main character's assault rifle's shock burst feature. It can be used to disable and knockback all of the robotic enemies (every single enemy is robotic except for one boss fight) and can be recharged from battery pickups the enemies drop. I didn't find myself using that often except against bosses; the range on the burst is fairly short compared to your normal rifle range and getting that close to a horde of enemies is a rather bad idea. On the topic of bosses, there are MANY of them, and most of them are fun to fight against (with the exception of the gorilla robot boss that you fight twice who is nothing but a gigantic pain in the ♥♥♥, and the transforming mech motorcycle which is nothing but an HP sink).

The game features an upgradable weapon system, not only for the main assault rifle but also for the weapons of your teammates. I'll go ahead and say that upgrading your allies' weapons is completely useless; you won't always be able to use your teammate of choice and most of their usefulness isn't in their firepower: it's in reviving you when you get downed and acting as a temporary decoy. The other upgrading system is the nanomachine system. Each character has a 2x3 grid on which to place dots (representing nanomachines) of various shapes. Most of them just increase health/defense/health regeneration/melee power, but there are exceptions, like Faye's nanomachines to increase her sniping accuracy. Several characters also have nanomachines that allow them to carry more revival medkits (I recommend these since, as I said, a large part of their usefulness is in reviving you when you get downed).

Now, about teammates...throughout most of the game you are allowed to create a squad of 3 characters (the main character + 2 teammates of your choice) from a selection of 4-5 teammates. Big Bo uses an assault rifle and is fairly tanky, Charlie uses an SMG, Rachael uses a shotgun and explosives, Faye uses a sniper rifle, and Cain uses a machine pistol and frequent melee (and is also, in my experience, the tankiest character). In battle you can give them orders, which they may or may not follow based on their current trust in you, which brings us to the trust system.

Characters in your party can gain or lose trust in you several ways. The most common way to gain trust is simply to do exceptionally well in battle; not only will they compliment you during the battle itself (and gain trust immediately), but it also creates a chance for them to open a dialogue with you after battle and gain even MORE trust. Several times throughout the 6 chapters characters will also stop you in hallways (or in other non-combat areas like elevators) and start a story-based dialogue there wherein they ask you questions. You can respond affirmatively/helpfully (almost always the correct" choice to gain trust) or negatively/sarcastically (which almost universally loses trust). Shooting teammates of course drops their trust in you (which is quite annoying when they run right in front of you as you're shooting)
date: and reviving them during battle gains their trust. The last (and in my experience least common) way to gain experience is to listen to their suggestions/orders during combat (for instance
recommended: if someone tells you to throw a grenade and you do so
hoursPlayed: you'll generally gain some trust from that person).\n\nThe trust system is important not so much from the fact that teammates will more likely follow your orders (I can count on one hand the number of times I actually issued orders as it wasn't typically necessary or even useful) but from the fact that it IMPACTS YOUR ENDING. Yes

reviewText: First things first.\nThis game has the most atrocious mouse acceleration" I've ever encountered.  It's actually a negative acceleration.  So it moves faster the faster you move the mouse
recommended:
and then it moves slower.  It's the most unnatural and awkward control I've ever experienced in a shooter.  You will be over-adjusting or under-adjusting your aim constantly.

This alone might be a deal-breaker for some people.  After playing through the whole campaign I was able to aim pretty well but still wasn't "used" to it.  I wasn't able to find a way to disable this "feature".


This game is silly.
Mostly in a good way.  The term "over the top" really wasn't in the developer's vocabulary.  So
hoursPlayed: this is pretty awesome for ridiculous boss fights and mayhem.  Some of which made me reminiscent of old school Contra games.  One thing that is obvious though is that some set pieces are stolen directly from other games/movies.  The biggest offenders being a canal sequence with a helicopter dropping mines on you (HL2).  And a transformer chasing you that was directly ripped from Revenge of the Fallen.  And a musical piece that is a carbon copy of Mona Lisa overdrive from Matrix 2.  Combat with the stock enemies is fun.  Getting headshots especially satisfying.  The tactical "commands" you can give your squadmates are limited

reviewText: It's a generic third-person cover-based shooter with an interesting story and cool characters. The voice recognition feature hardly works but even if it did it's much easier to just give out the recommended commands using a controller. All of the conversations amongst crew mates are fairly shallow and it's very easy to deduce what reply will gain you their trust. Because of this it's very easy to gain max trust with someone and I've never had a crew member disobey an order. The online multiplayer community is dead so unless you have a friend to play with don't expect to connect to any matches. Still, it's a pretty fun game so I recommend it if you can get it for cheap.

The AI for your partners aren't exactly smart either since every now and again they'll like to run in front of you while you're firing at baddies then when you hit them because of that they'll blame you for shooting at them and then your trust level will go down with them. Game's got recharging health and when you take enough damage you go into a sort of last-stand kind of thing where you can crawl around and shoot with your pistol before time takes your life to a mission failure status. You can either recover yourself from the last stand thing with a medkit if you have at least one OR you can ask one of your partners to help you out of it. Half the time though I found that they'll be idiots and keep shooting at the enemies instead of going with their agreement to help you out of dying status. The last stand thing takes a long time to actually kill you too unless a baddie helps speed that up.\nSpecific robot body parts can be shot off for better or worse. If you shoot a leg off of a basic robot it will start to crawl. Shoot its firing arm it will stop firing. However if you shoot one's head off it will attack the other robots instead of you. reviewText:
This is really fun! The combat (while derivative of other TPS) is solid, and the enemies, the 'robot-gore', and the environments are cool. The game also looks great, and the design is fantastic as well - the cityscape is wonderful to look at and really feels like a great blend of sci-fi futurism and gritty realism, and the character models are detailed and instantly recognisable. But the strongest feature of the game (in my opinion) are the cutscenes. The script is well written and the performances are pitch perfect and committed across the board. More importantly, I can follow the story and am invested in the characters, and I'm enjoying this more and more as it goes on.

I didn't realise that voice-recognition was such a big part of the game, and while it's gimmicky and can be frustrating at times, it is great fun at times to yell 'charge!' at one of your characters and have them respond to the command, throwing themselves into the enemy.

Everything that's great about it certainly makes up for any shortcomings in my opinion.

reviewText: I've only got an hour on this but the single-player game play is interesting -- so far the antagonists are all humanoid robots.  Apparently on account of this being a PC port, the setup mechanism leaves much to be desired; the main setup appears to not be accessible in game, you have to quit the game and start the configuration utility to remap a key or make any video changes (the original key mappings are unusual for PC gaming).   The graphics look good on max settings though the game is not that well optimized; I had to force the game to run in SLI by choosing AFR2 in Nvidia settings, I also chose multi-core rendering and disabled vsync in favor of gsync (this helped a lot).  It's on sale as I write this for $4.00 -- the game and all the DLC -- so far, it's worth it.  Haven't tried the steam control or an xbox controller yet.

reviewText:
Binary Domain is a bit of an unpolished, overlooked gem. It delivers an engaging, well told, but fairly familiar story; with well designed and varied locations, but extremely linear missions. Gameplay borrows heavily from Mass Effect both in action and dialogue and is pretty solid, offering the player a wide array of squad-mates to choose from, each well fleshed-out with their own skills, with enough unique bosses and enemy types to keep things interesting. Though several issues (on rails section, poor upgrade / health mechanic)  hold it back a bit from being as good as it could have been.

Here is my full in-depth review
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TaiEVRmOjwY

reviewText:
Definitely worth playing if you like games like Gears of War, Mass Effect, Metal Gear or movies like James Bond, Terminator, GI Joe. It has a feel of you being part of a unique squad of GI Joes. It has the background storyline similar to Terminator, it has the combat feel of Gears of War mixed with Metal Gear, and it has the team building aspects of Mass Effect.

The game is quite linear and feels like an Action Movie that you are a major part of. There are choices you can make in the game that change what happens in the scenes. I hear there are more than one ending in the game, but the ending I got looked real enough to be the best. I'll probably play through more to see if I can get the worst ending.

Now if you use the Voice Recognition System it is a little bit buggy. I found it best to use a headset with mic to prevent background noise from messing it up. Being able to say things in combat like Fire, Cover Me, Fall Back, Need Assitance, Blitz, Charge, Yes, No, Affirmative was truly amazing. During combat if you fall you go into a last stand with your pistol and a teammate will ask if you need assistance and if you say yes they will try to make it to you but it's not their main priority; I only say yes if I don't have a medkit on me. Also you can talk to any team mate by saying their name while the voice com is on. Like even if they aren't on your current team and it's funny cause they will always tell you to focus on your current objective. The background noise of my surround sound system was being picked up by my microphone and catching words of the dialogue and the characters thought I was saying things I wasn't even saying which made me think of the headset idea which was a better way in playing the game.

I liked using my Xbox360 controller but to each their own. It doesn't tell you the buttons of the xbox controller but it will give you the keyboard commands for the action moments. I just memorized what each button was on the keyboard and in my head I would press it on the Xbox360 controller. It was more fun for me to play it on that.

The loyalty system reminds me of Mass Effect but way better. You have the between combat down time to create dialogue to improve their characters loyalty. In combat is the main bonus of this though. In combat if you shoot your teammate they lose loyalty, but you can also praise them for covering you, tell them they did a good job at the last thing they did and you will build a relationship with these NPCs like they were actual team mates. The loyalty system also improves the team mates that are currently on your team in combat when you take out more than one enemy using a grenade, bosonic blast, rocket, or using an environmental explosion. Your active team mates loyalty also improves if you melee kill or one shot kill the enemy during combat situations too. The loyalty system determines if they obey you in combat or try to do their own thing. I had one person hate me at first because I kept shooting them when they got in the way, but instead using the Voice Recognition System with a headset every time they got in the way I would tell them to Fall Back and Cover Me and praise them for doing a Good Job or Nice Work and now they are one of my most trusted team mates.

The storyline draws you in and keeps you there. There are twists and turns, there are unique situations that are amazing. One team mate is full of surprises, you will see what I mean when you play, but they are my favorite so far.

The enemies are different. They are robots that each have a weakness. Some are color coded to show you the way they will attack. Each boss has a unique way of dying and you listen to your team mates or try to analyze the weakness of each from fighting the boss. After fighting a few bosses you will be able to figure out what some of the other bosses weak points are. Each boss has a unique feel to it, but they are all well made.

It's not always combat, combat, combat. It has some scenes you play your character through that made it feel like an old James Bond movie just set in the future, which is funny because one part in the game they mention James Bond and the character being called it doesn't know who James Bond is, but another character does.

There is character progression. Each character has a unique weapon that is a part of their character class even the main character. That weapon can be upgraded at kiosks around the game. Each character also can be outfitted with nanobots that can improve the character from healing, health total, defense, reload time, grenade number, health kit number.

Other weapons. In the game almost all enemies except bosses drop weapons you can pickup and use. These weapons can range from shotguns, to smgs, to assault rifles, to sniper rifles, to chain guns. You can also find guns laying around. You carry your pistol, your main gun, a grenade type there are several, and a second gun that you can find. Chain Guns and the Stinger Missle are Heavy guns and don't require you to drop a secondary weapon and are fun to use. You can use some Gun Mounts you find throughout the game. The grenade types you can use are Frag, Remote Detonation, Spiked/Sticky grenades, EMP, and Holographic Decoys are what I have found so far.

I beat the main story in less than 11 hours. I haven't tried multiplayer either or even know if the multiplayer works. I do recommend this game to anyone that likes those types of games and movies. It has it's own unique feel and I believe everyone should try it at least once.

reviewText:
An overall solid game. For an obviously Japanese production, it wasn't too bad.

Pros:+Robots. Holy ♥♥♥♥, these are some of the most awesome robots I've ever seen. If there is one thing I admire about the Japanese, it's their ability to completely give reason and logic the middle finger and do what they want. And this time it actually paid off.

+Gunplay. Guns felt good to use and had decent animations, but variety was lacking. Each robot has multiple layers to it's libs and body, meaning dismemberment and the animations to back it up. Shooting the legs will force them to crawl, destroying the right arm will make them pick up a gun with their left, and destroying their head will send them into a frenzy.

+Storyline. A few cliches here and there, but in the end it was a thrilling story with more than it's fair share of plot twists. Even if it was pushing a heavy-handed political agenda.

+Animations. Big plus here, the animations are very good in and out of cutscenes.

+Camera. Cutscenes and in-game camera are done incredibly well. Some of the best of what I've seen from this genre.

+-Characters. I love most and hate a few. Given it's Japanese origins, characters are incredibly cliche. Male characters are all buff and wear thick armor, but a few missions in and the game goes out of it's way to oversexualise the introduction of an Asian sniper donning a skin-tight combat outfit thing. Yeah, because I've never seen the sexy sniper" character before
date: right? Her whole character is so cringe-worthy that I actually like the tom-boy Pointman female character that is introduced in a much more believable fashion in the same mission. Ending on a positive note
recommended: every character has their own personality and way that they handle things
hoursPlayed: which is interesting and sometimes humorous.\n\n+-Trust/Relationship System. Squad members trust you more if you agree with what you say (usually) and distrust you if you harm them or insult them in communication. The relationship part is downright bad. You could tell it was coming from a mile away (and hated the idea from the beginning)
voteText: but in standard Japanese cliche fashion
helpfulPercent: the skintight sniper falls for the strong and brash soldier. Go figure
votesHelpful: right?\n\n+Art style. Sorry for all you anime fans
votesTotal: but this game lacks your standard anime conventions (which is probably the main reason I even considered picking the game up). You can tell it's a Japanese production
votesFunny: but it's art style is realistic and believable.\n\nCons:-+Voice Acting. It was actually really hard to put this in the cons section instead of the pros section
commentsCount: but all in all the voice acting is lacking. At times the voice can articulate genuine emotions that can really make the moment
column16: especially the main character. The majority of other characters sound like they're just reading off a piece of paper
column17: while with minor characters it sounds like they didn't even try.\n\n-Controls. The controls are pretty hit and miss. In events where the 'w' and 's' key are to be used
column18: it will display the whole 'wasd' layout as if there are more options than there really are. When only the 'a' and 'd' keys are used

column20: when the LMB is to be used

column22: you should be able to say certain words and the game will use them to talk to characters and issue commands. In reality
column23: the whole feature is busted and ineffective. But it can be disabled
column24:
so it's really no big deal.

Overall7/10
Binary Domain is definitely a game worth playing more than once. With multiple endings

reviewText:
The year is 2080. The world as we know it have changed in some matters. There are robots in use for common tasks (e.g. ecurity, police, secretary). Other than that, because of the climat changes the water level rose which resulted in massive floods which was unfortuante for many countries, like Japan.
The members of Rust Crew - a global task-force created by the International Robotics Technology Association are covertly dispatched to Tokyo. Their objective is to investigate reports of Amada Corporation's developement of human-like robots.
This mission is a follow-up for the event that took place 10 days before which confirmed the existance of Hollow Children (that's how these robots are called). One of them showed up in Detroid's facility of Bergen Corporation - the current monopolist in robot industry.
The interactive part begins on the Japan's capital oustkirts, where the player is acquainted with Dan (playable character) and Bo - the Yankee part of Rust Crew.
After a brief warm-up with the controlling scheme our buds are beeing spotted and atacked by robots patrolling this area. So much for stealth operation, from there there's only dynamic action.
There's gonna be a lot of robots in different forms ans sizes. For dealing with them Dan is equipped with few weapons and granades.
As You might expect from third person shooter the further progress will result encountering stronger enemies. To make it possible to survive them, there are upgrades for each character and for their primary weapons.
You'll also often use covers. The same goes for the enemies, except the bosses. Heavy metal beasts doesn't need to hide and requires more firepower to take them out.
So, from what I described You might think it's like Gears of War, right? That's correct, although there are some things that makes this title being not recommended in my eyes.
While the combat is entertaining (although a bit flawed, because of companions a.l.), the graphics is still good and the whole concept of robots in disguise is great I don't like the execution. Why is that? Let me explain my point of view.
Endlessly shooting becomes boring after some time. It would be nice to have more variety in gameplay.
The Rust Crew dialogues are at least medicore. Some lines are used too often. Surprisingly the voice acting is good.
The voice command system – the problem with recognizing words is not a big deal, but there should be a possibility to make responds from assigned buttons.
My biggest issue is that this world deserves a better, deeper game with more variety in gameplay. You see, when I saw trailer for the first time I was like – damn, dis gon b gud. I've been expecting Matrix mixed with Terminator. The more time I spend with Binary Domain, the more I realized I got Enter the Matrix. Similar in level of disappointment.
Other than that the game is fine, so if you don't have high hopes – buy it and have fun. It's worth it's price.
If You are interested in multiplayer then check the community – there are still a few people who wants to play online.

reviewText:
Bland & lazy // Recommended for people who want to shoot robots & can be bothered with little else
Steam Review Showcase:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ox_R-g8VAno&feature=youtu.be

+ Many of the environments are spectacular, particularly in the upper city (Chapter 3+)
+ Quality of voice-acting (with some noticable exceptions) is mostly quite good, especially those of the Japanese characters
+ Visuals generally range from moderate to good, and have generally aged respectably since release
+ There is a good sense of level design, with lots of available cover and attention to detail
+ TPS cover mechanics, and overall movement and gunplay, are all par-for-the-course; they're nothing new, but certainly well-implemented and enjoyable
+ Enemies are dynamically destructible; limbs can be shot off, heads can be removed, etc.
+ Collectibles mostly consist of data files that can be accessed from the main menu, and are admittedly interesting to read

- Multiplayer appears to be 100% dead
- Trust system, while an interesting mechanic on paper, is completely broken in practice; trust seems to rise exponentially regardless of your actions, and is a thin veneer of a gameplay mechanic
- Bosses are bland and little more than bullet-sponges that focus wholeheartedly on destroying a series of glowing 'weak spots' in order to take them down; there is nothing innovative in any of these fights
- Game desperately tries to be funny, but its efforts are a constant distraction; every cringe-worthy line is disastrously obnoxious
- Most interactions with teammates are lifeless responses that tend to boil down to 'yes' or 'no'
- Plot is uninspired, lazily written, and otherwise ruined by a rather extreme oversight (plot hole)
- Game tries to force a plethora of poorly written emotional and romantic moments down the player's throat; they are universally weak and will fail to move even the most sensitive viewer
- Attempts at character development are atrocious at best
- Voice-controls are clunky and awkward; they're hardly needed in combat to begin with, and are really little more than a gimmicky feature

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Also, feel free to join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements. Thanks for reading!

James Rolfe would say the first feature of a game should be 'being able to play it'. Despite the misleading 'full controller support' label, controllers usually don't work properly.

Cons:

I would have continued if the controls were the least bit managable...but when I have to hit a button more than once to jump over, change cover and almost everything else. reviewText: Gears of War w/ Robots has decent mechanics and pretty graphics... for a last gen console game. This port feels unintuitive to my PC gamer side, and slightly clunky to my 360-player side. Besides the iffy controls and binding options, there's a companion command system that uses your microphone; speak to command. A good idea in theory, but the constant clacking of my keyboard is enough to keep the AI constantly complaining about my mumbling or spontaneously run to their deaths. This is exacerbated by a lack of press-to-talk and a dependence on this system to keep morale high. All of this is AFTER tweaking and optimizing my mic settings.\nUnrelated is SEGA's use of LAST decade's Big-Book-of-Tropes, with a cocky protag, exotic" love interest
date: and ..."slight" racial and societal stereotyping. Do I recommend the PC port of Binary Domain? ...No. Go for the console versions if you feel like nothing else quite tickles your fancy like Gears of War did."

This game was probably very good on Xbox 360. But on PC it's an absolute piece of s h i t. Luckily this game was free, 'cause there'd be no way in hell i'd pay for this piece of s h i t

reviewText: I played the demo once, and I thought it was fairly cool. Then I tried the actual game, and I got an allergic reaction.\n\nWeird control scheme, confusing on-screen directions, awful intro, terrible story (if there is one), an annoying cover system, lots of cutscenes and a load of upgrades for all the different characters in your team. I don't have much playtime to make this review overly useful, but my first impression wasn't very good. I felt I just had to stop playing. I think it's safe to say, that you're not missing out on much if you skip it.

reviewText: Hoo boy... I wanted to like this game, I really did, becasue it's a cyberpunk shooter. But this game won't allow me. First off, there's no reload button. If you want to reload, you have to empty out what you've got. Secondly, the setup window is way too large, and can't be resized, so if you have a low-resolution monitor, you're screwed as far as setting up goes. Nextly, a lot of the times it tells you to press a key on Keyboard, it tells you the wrong key, or doesn't even know itself. The lowest sensitivity is a bit too fast, but can be gotten used to. I'm just glad I didn't pay for this game (Thanks to the Make War Not Love promotion SEGA did), and I feel bad for anyone who did. If you REALLY want to try this game out, at least try the demo first, but I highly recommend looking elsewhere for a good game.

reviewText:
if you checking this game out and reading the review because you are wondering about getting it off the hummm.... sale... well i do have to say its worth it. the controls are wierd. it doesnt react like a normal shooter does. one thing it does not show or tell you at all is you can use a mic to tell your team mate in single player what to do. now you do not need a mic but it does help when your under fire. dev try ti make thing diff by changing controles, story lines, graphics, ect. i played about two hours into the game and im hooked. i recomend checking the game out if you get if for a few bucks. also another thing, when the game promps you to use your charge wepon it says press and hold M. not M the button but the middle mouse button. i had to exit and check the controls to figure this out. so just double check the controls befor playing.
the pros of this game is awesome performance, graphics, and the ability to upgrade your wepons and give your player nanites for abilitys like 10% health or wepon damage. you also get to upgrade your team as well. plays like a shooter but dances like an RPG.
the cons are controls. now this doesnt mean its unplayable. it will just take some time to get use to it. after about 45 mins i picked it up. no jumping. you use space bar for most everything. and with out a mic it can take you some time to tell your team mate what to do.
but all in all in a nut shell. go for it. im having a lot of fun and i hope to see you in muli player because it is still active.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Binary Domain is a halfway decent 3rd person shooter with a LOT of rough edges and weird bits.  I got it for free from a Sega promotion, and I would have been ♥♥♥♥♥♥ if I'd paid any actual money for it.

The shooter aspects of the game are fine, nothing spectacular but competently executed.  I shot a lot of robots in the junk; can't complain about that.  The boss fights are pretty fun, although they have a tendency to stunlock you in weird ways.  The main character's assault rifle is upgradeable, and I was shredding robot limbs like leafy greens on a Food Network show by the end.  There were one or two puzzle moments" where I had to use the gun's "bosonic charge" or whatever to break barrels that weren't having any of this "bullet" business.

There's some squad tactics and such
date: but this is a mess.  There's a voice command feature that is a neat gimmick for about thirty seconds
recommended: as those things are wont to be.  My squadmates rarely did anything useful
hoursPlayed: and at LEAST once per encounter they decided that standing between me and the enemy was a smart thing to do.  If I get good kills
voteText: they compliment me
helpfulPercent: with the same phrase ad nauseum.  All of them are just-this-side-of-racist caricatures of stereotypical nationalities.  The French robot in particular stopped just short of going "oh hoh hoh" at the end of every phrase.  The dialog is pretty bad
votesHelpful: and it's delivered pretty poorly to boot.   The audio in cutscenes is poorly balanced
votesTotal: with the dialog being drowned out by the music.\n\nThe plot is... convoluted
votesFunny: full of holes
commentsCount: and becomes utter garbage in the last act.  I caught bits and pieces of it
column16: at one point they were talking about having sex with robots
column17: there was a cutscene where I swear a dude was feeling up a rack of servers
column18: and in another part there was a literal triple cross.  A character changed sides and then changed sides again within the span of about 2 minutes.\n\nBinary Domain is also a pretty awful console port.  The mouse and keyboard controls are okay for the most part
column19: but they're totally busted in several sequences involving fixed guns and a "tank" sequence I hit at one point.  I was throwing my mouse across the pad 5-10 times to get my character to turn 90 degrees in any direction.   The gamepad controls might be better
column20: but it didn't work with my Xbox One controller at all.  Trying to move the camera just made it spin in circles.  Often times
column21: the button prompts were maddeningly nonspecific
column22: telling me to press a mouse button but not which one
column23: or just showing a "[_]" icon instead of a key.\n\nSo it's a halfway decent shooter with a lot of worthless experimental elements
column24: terrible AI
column25: an overly convoluted story
column26: and it's a bad port of a console game.  Metal Gear Solid fans will love it!"

reviewText:
This game was a lot funner than i thought it would be. At first glance, all i could see were the faults. Broken audio recongnition, button prompts not corresponding to the correct key, and needing to close the game in order to adjust the keybindings were almost enough to break the game for me. I stuck with it though and i found myself having tons of fun.

I never expected blowing up robots to be so much fun. This game has a suprisingly deep story, and threw me for a complete loop on multiple occasions. The boss battles were also a sorely missed addition to the FPS genre. My jaw dropped  once i found the Gold Plated Transformer. The multi-stage boss battles are just fun.

Another thing this game does right is the first guy to die isn't a black guy, so that's worth 8/10 right there. Buy this game, it is totally worth it.

reviewText:
This game is exactly what it claims to be and nothing more; something that is sort of refreshing nowadays since the marketing of games hardly ever matches the reality. I tend to not prefer 3rd person shooters because the controls on a keyboard always seem to be a little odd. And that oddness is present here but not as extreme as others Ive played. The quarkiness is actually extremely mild and barely affects game play. Certain mouse movements are really sensitive but ocne you get used to the controls the game  is exactly what I expected.

While this isnt a scream of a game it has some really great attributes. Sega tends to have quite a few cut scenes with amazing graphics. On Binary Domain, some of the cut scenes rival some of the most popular games currently being released. The other half of the cut scenes are just ok graphically speaking and a few are a little annoying because they seem unecessary. There are many times where you get a short cut scene and then have to go back to the game to do something as simple as walk down a hallway or pathway and do nothing more before triggering another mediocre cut scene. I dont know why they designed the game this way.

Another annoyance is your team mates say the same things over and over again and frequently. Its a minor annoyance but they couldve just reduced the frequency of the NPC commentary and most of what they said would go unnoticed. Also, the secret" datapads look like they do any many other games and are so easy to find that its actually hard to miss them. Since the game is totally linear all you have to do when following the path is look for a small extension of the hallway
recommended: etc and walk over there...theres your secret datapad
hoursPlayed:
every time.

Now for the good stuff...

On each level/section you can select which team mates you want to bring with you based on their skills and how far along youve been able to upgrade their skills. Which brings me to my second pro of this game
voteText: the player and NPC (non-playable character) upgrades. You never seem to have enough $ to upgrade everything and everyone
helpfulPercent: which is good. This puts you into the position of having to make choices. But when your characters are upgradaed well and you select the right character to accompany you on a mission it does help out a lot
votesHelpful:
even though most of the responsibility falls on you.

Theres a lot of action i n the game. Thats always a plus for a shooter.

The default keybindings
votesTotal: while different from every other game
votesFunny: seem to make more sense and be totally fluid for a 3rd person shooter. I actually think other 3rd person shooters would be better off to copy these default keybindings and actions. It took me a little while to adapt but when I did it felt like second nature.\n\nPrice. Ive seen this game go on sale a couple times and when it does it is pretty darn cheap. And that makes this totally worth buying when its on sale. Would I recommend the game
commentsCount: absolutely. If you watch eny preview videos or even game play online
column16: you can easily tell exactly what youre getting. It doesnt break any new ground but it also doesnt lose ground either. Also
column17: keep in mind that the game isnt brand-spanking-new. But to be honest
column18:
its hard to tell at times.

Overall 7/10

"

reviewText:
Not the best PC port out there, there are a few niggles so you will spend some time with the configuration program at first to get the controls and settings right, and even then you won't be able to turn off the mouse acceleration (I hope they include that in a future patch).

However, beyond those niggles it's quite an awesome third person shooter, with a good story to boot. The bosses are very diverse and shooting the robots to bits so their debris fly all over, is quite satisfying! Not to mention the robots are pretty damn cool in the sense that they never really give up, shoot off their arm and they pick up their weapon with the other arm, shoot their legs and they start to crawl towards you and so on.

So yeah, I highly recommend this game! Only played the single player campaign though, so I can't comment on the multiplayer aspect of it.

reviewText:
Bought it in the winter sale because i read somewhere sometime it was supposedly good but nobody played it. Looked somewhat like Vanquish, was cheap so hey.

Now after finishing it and having had a great deal of fun im kinda puzzled why this went so unnoticed. Sure its a third person cover shooter - but really well done.

- Slick presentation, levels are linear but well designed, varied in theme (not only metal corridors) and have a good flow throughout
- Regulary breaks up runnning and gunning with different types of action sequences which are all good (even when conceptionally lifted from other games - theres a jet ski sequence in a canal where a thing drops bombs on you, seemed familiar)
- Only 3 or so QTEs in the whole game
- Manages to make shooting only robots not dull since they break apart and explode quite nicely
- Nice feeling of weight for lack of a better description, rocket impacts and such send you flailing and some of the bigger bosses toss you around something fierce (having a controller with rumble feature helps i guess)
- Good story, the obvious twist gets averted with a more unlikely one but eh. Good characterization for the squad, theres only one stereotype but he is pretty cool and your bro yo and the Brit doesnt say Mate even once i think.

Gameplaywise its a third person cover shooter. You have one main weapon you cant change, infinite ammo pistol and a second slot" for a variety of other weapons like snipz0r rifles and rocket launchers. Blindfire
recommended:
etc.
You can upgrade weapons and buy upgrades like more health with murderpoints you get from murdering robots at shops strewn about. The upgrade system is a little different - the upgrades are like Tetris pieces with a specific attribute each and wherever you put those on (in?) your body only has a limited amount of space.

You get to pick which sidekicks to take with you at the start of a mission or certain interludes. Doesnt result in branching paths (e.g. if you take one dude instead of the other he can hack an otherwise closed door or something like that) but of course theres different dialoge and also theres a trust meter which builds by just having them along or doing and saying stuff they like - done over a a little "pick your reply" window which otherwise is used for commands like regrouping and such. The trust rating affects mainly the ending and a few other cutscenes
hoursPlayed:
its no Mass Effect but a nice addition.

Downsides :
- Keyboard and Mouse control sucks? Didnt try
- The big gimmick is supposedly voice recognition for the replies and commands. From reading the forums that doesnt work well and also why bother
voteText: "standard" method works good enough. Besides

reviewText: I'll say one thing right off the bat; it's fun. That being said, don't expect any writing worthy of an award. It's bad. It's really bad. You thought it was going to be an existential piece full of questions and morals? Well think again. Either the Japanese really can't write anything without being too comical or cartoonish or it's just simply a parody. In fact, I'm sure it's a parody. While the overall design is really cyberpunk and reminescent of 90s sci-fi (which I personally really do like) albeit wacky in its own right, the extremely poor story overshadows the overall experience and point of it all, eventually turning it into a simplistic shooter. Shoot 'em up. Shoot all the robots, end of story. If you can get past without irritation at the totally pointless dialogue options with no consequence or value whatsoever. Worth your money? If you can spare a buck. I wouldn't hold it high on my wishlist. Then there's the technical side of it all. A really crappy console port with poor support and optimization, broken ''voice support'' and clunky controls and practically no graphical customization, not that it's really necessary anyway.  Do I recommend this game? If I had to choose between Yes and No, I'd go for a ''Eh, whatever.''

reviewText:
I haver been trying to get this game to work for several months now to no avail.  I have given up.

The game needs to run the Configuartion tool before you can play it.  In the Configuartion tool I set all my graphics settings and options and go to save it but wait...  there is no option to save your config?   That's right, you cannot save your config.  So I X out of it hoping that it will save in the background, I try to launch the game again... PLEASE RUN THE CONFIG TOOL.

I guess SEGA doesn't want me to play the game I purchased from them.

I also guess SEGA doesn't want me to purchase any other games from them.

Good job SEGA, you lost a customer of 25 years.  I still have my Genesis, but I wont look at it too fondly anymore.


EDIT: I fixed it, no thanks to SEGA. This game is installed on my projector PC which is 720p. The conflig tool wont show the SAVE & QUIT button if your resolution is 720, so I changed the PCs resolution to 1080 and the button appeared. I then saved my setting and changed it back to 720p and it now works.

This is a really stupid issue with the game that should have been fixed years ago. I had tried maybe 3-4 times to get this game running and it was a resolution issue this whole time...

reviewText:
One of the worst games and PC ports I ever had the displeasure of experiencing, what a complete joke. A horrible console port where A is Space, B is F, Y is... Y for some reason and you reload with the mouse wheel? The cursor (which doesn't exist in the menus at all) moves slower if you move it fast and fast if you move it slow. I'm utterly convinced NOT ONE PC player tested this before dumping it on Steam.

All this could probably have been forgiven if the game itself was any good, but apparently that is too much to ask. A Mass Effect wannabe in the most superficial way possible, Binary Domain is a 1990s straight-to-video B-movie with cringeworthy dialog, zero character and a blatant ripoff of so many games, movies and novels on transhumanism.

I know I'll never get those two and a half hours back, but maybe my suffering will spare yours.

reviewText:
Great graphics and effects, solid gameplay, good sound. And the story is epic, one of the coolest stories in a game I've ever gotten to see. And holy ♥♥♥♥ are there a lot of cutscenes: you will be watching cutscenes as much as you get to play, so put your controller in your lap, cross your fingers and wait for the cutscenes to end and let you back in the action. It seems like Resident Evil 6 took all of its inspiration from this game in that regard. But at least they are very well done very cool and fun to watch and the voice acting is mostly pretty good.

Because of numerous technical issues and this being the worst port I've ever seen control-wise, catch it on sale. Port job is 4/10, otherwise game is easily a 8/10. If you have the awful mouse acceleration problem, use a xbox controller.

-Mouse Control Issue-
Because of a horrible mouse acceleration problem that they are not ever going to fix, mouse and keyboard controls are out of the question. It is really bad. So you need to have a xbox 360 controller and only that. Any other controllers you might have issues with. Even then, each time you start the game, white it is running you have to unplug and plug it back in for the controls to work right. Even then you have to set the controller sensitivity to the lowest setting 1, because anything above is too high, so you can minimize the acceleration problem which is STILL there even for the controller but not nearly as bad as the mouse. EVEN THEN!!!... you need to unplug the controller and plug it back in ONLY at the main menu, you cannot do it during gameplay.
-Voice Commands-
The voice commands in the game do not work properly. Most of the time I am saying the command clearly but it will still not register or registers as something else, so you will have to turn off voice commands.

reviewText: This game is barley playable.  Hinges mostly on mic, won't detect my mouse that's otherwise working.  All control schemes tried by me and a friend were wonkey, be it keyboard and mouse, xbox 360 or xbox one controler.  The xbox controlers in fact didn't even let you turn.  The weapons mapping on 1-4 were unintuitive ties with the keyboard (one was at the 9:00 instead of 12:00 position).  This game feals like a console game, that was quickly ported to PC.  But not that little attention to detail was put on the keyboard/mouse, but it surprises me to see xbox controlers bad enough to not be functional.  Additionally, xbox controlers use triggers to look up and down instead of right thumbstick... WHAT?!  My fingers are FAR from precise enough to look up and down without looking WAY too far up and down.  The invasion mode was too simplistic (not too easy, challenge level was OK, but just low variety of enemy, and super small map).  Outside of these things, the game showed a lot of potential.  Fun" was within grasp
date: but just barley slipped away.  I wanted to like this
recommended: it sounded really good.  Unfortunately that wasn't the case."

reviewText: TL;DR Version:It's a third person shooter by the Yakuza team, it's really good.\nBinary Domain is a third person cover" based shooter with squad mechanics. If this was done by an unknown team or a team known for making mediocre titles which I thought was thanks to written reviews by ♥♥♥♥ websites (I was a baddie back then) and the cover being bland when the game was first released. Then one day while going through wikipedia I learned that the game was made by the team that makes the Yakuza games... I bought the game straight afterwards without thinking. The Yakuza team is apart of SEGA and they have been making the only good series SEGA has published in the last 10 years and I was interested how a team that focuses on making over the top 3D brawlers with huge storylines make a third person shooter let alone while they were making Yakuza 5 which is massive in terms in content and I was shocked on how good Binary Domain is.\nBinary Domain has you fighting against robots in the city of Tokyo as Dan "The Survivor" Marshall
date: A man that earns that title on the basis he isn't dead and his squad built of a comedy relief American black man named Big Bo
recommended: a Chinese sniper named Faye Lee that looks like someone from one of the pornos that Big Bo watches in his spare time
hoursPlayed: an MI6 soldier named Charlie that complains a lot and British demo expert that I forget the name of because I never brought her in missions and three other characters that I won't spoil.\n\nThe gameplay is standard for the genre besides one thing
voteText: since the enemies are robots you can destroy limbs and they will take it in stride for the most part
helpfulPercent: removal of arms will make them less accurate and make them drop their gun
votesHelpful: removal of legs will make them crawl or hop and removal of the head causes the AI to go nuts and makes them attack other robots
votesTotal: headshots also make a nice little ding noise when you do it which I love
votesFunny: also while shooting enemies their armor falls off with sounds of metal clanging on the floor exposing their wires and such. This system and guns being really fun to use make this some of the most fun I've had with a third person shooter in a long time if not shooters in general since the game rewards you with credits if you go balls deep in battles while saying ♥♥♥♥ you to cover(Hence the "" in the word cover in paragraph 1)while blasting bot heads off moving fire away from you so you can do it again and thankfully your health pool isn't small so you can easily do this but you still need to rest every once in a while during battles on harder settings. Since this is a squad based game you AI partners and they are actually really good at what they do
commentsCount: they can kill enemies and protect themselves while following orders given by you thanks to the games voice comm system which I never used so I just used the pre select options from the tab menu
column16: squadmates also have a trust meter which is increased if you perform headshots
column17: melee kills and if you "go balls deep". Trust affects the game's ending if everyone is at max trust which is hard to do on a first playthrough since you have no knowledge on who you might have at different times
column18: don't bother with this until a 2nd playthrough where you know what you'll have.\n\nThere are some other stuff in the game but it's 1am and I've written more about a single video game than my latest english exam about a poem which I looked at for an hour so in conclusion... Binary Domain is good game 9/10 go buy it."

reviewText:
Review:

Let me first start off by saying I went into this game not expecting some groundbreaking experience. I didn't expect expert storywriting, the best acting a voice actor could muster, or some top of the line gameplay. Coming out of it, I can safely confirm this game has none of that. HOWEVER, what it does have is a damn good story, some good gameplay, some good voice acting. Nothing top of the line, but good for what it's worth.

Binary Domain is a 3rd person Tactical cover based shooter. Immediate the whole cover-based shooter" will send alarms ringing in many people's heads
date: due to the market being over saturated with it. Despite this pandering to that market
recommended: I gotta say it does it pretty damn well. Enemies are intelligent enough to move between cover and use cover responsibly.\n\nTaking place in a futuristic time
hoursPlayed: Binary Domain feels like it harkens back to the old age of games
voteText: where robots could be seen as an enemy. In a market over saturated with zombies and humans that aren't American or British being the enemies
helpfulPercent: fighting robots is a welcome change. While not original
votesHelpful: Binary Domain tackles the robot antagonist in a brilliant way. Like an actual robot
votesTotal: it takes a lot to chip away at them
votesFunny: since they aren't made out of squishy flesh and muscle. Taking off their arms
commentsCount: legs
column16: or even their heads don't get them to just stop. You just gotta keep shooting them till they drop and explode. It gives an old arcade like feel. Not to mention it gives the player different means of tackling situations. Taking out their legs forces them to a crawl
column17: while taking out their arms may limit their aiming
column18: but make them more aggressive. If you have the patience to go for a headshot

reviewText: Binary Domain is a fantastic team based FPS, with an excellent campaign storyline, polished squad interaction and a solid upgrade system.   Stripping robots of their armor with your assault rifle or downing behomoth bots has visceral appeal.  Although the voice controlled interaction gimick is a bit lackluster, it can be deactivated in favor of standard button control.  Binary Domain is a true overlooked diamond in the rough, a game that inexplicably didn't reach a wider audience.  While there have been some complaints about mouse and keyboard support, gamepad for pc works flawlessly.  In addition to widescreen and overlay support, the game features a multiplayer mode that is guaranteed to extend gameplay.  Unfortunately, the multiplayer base has diminished since release so be prepared to find friends to play with.

reviewText:
5/10
Worth playing through, but not on my must-play list. Another squad shooter in third-person. If you've got a decent mic, it has an interesting way of letting you give orders verbally, although it didn't work well for me.
Game gets pretty repetitive about halfway through, but the story is super gripping and makes you want to know what happens next anyways.
Just be aware, NOBODY plays the multiplayer. And that's okay, it's not exactly any more gripping than TF2's multiplayer anyways.
I'd say buy it if you want a story with some shooting and have some spare time, especially if it's on sale.

reviewText: A bit rough around the edges but introduces some interesting mechanics to what would otherwise be a fairly bog standard cover shooter. The first is voice commands which I would like to say allows you to quickly and easily give orders to your squad, is really useful and adds a new dimension to the gameplay but I can't, because although my mic was functioning fine the recognition of my broad northern english dialect did not team to work. The other interesting mechanic that I can say did work as intended was the armor destruction. This brought some entertainment to what otherwise would be very repetitive shooting sections. The core story tried to explore some interesting subject matter, but it did so through many one dimensional characters. Couple this with some shocking deviations from the main gameplay such as a terrible jet-ski section and I find it extremely difficult to understand how I enjoyed this game, But I did.\n\nYou can have a good time with this if you can get over the great many flaws.

reviewText:
I wish there was a MIXED Recommendation as I'm torn about this game.

The GOOD
------------
* Graphics are purdy
* Great voice acting
* Interesting (but predictable) story
* Soundtrack isn't bad
* It's a 3rd person Duck & Cover shooter I guess

The BAD
-------------
* Short (they make up for this by one-shotting you to death repeatedly with no time in-between rezzes to do anything, causing you to have to play an encounter over and over out of frustration until you've spent 10x longer an an encounter than it should have taken. There really is only 2 hours of content in this game without the artificial difficulty).
* 90% Cutscenes
* Might as well have been an On Rails Shooter"
* Bosses are QTEs. No matter how many bullets
recommended: gernades you throw at them they don't take damage unless you do the one exact thing in that one precise spot at the right time that the Devs are expecting you to do with no hints.\n* Accuracy is calculated by an in-game weapon skill
hoursPlayed:
not by real-life skill. You can be pixel-on and miss or be pointing at the opposite side of the screen and head-shot depending on the RNG.
* Predictable Story

After I play another game the only thing that I will remember about this one is that it was infuriating. Otherwise it is entirely forgettable."

reviewText: A surprisingly decent third-person shooter but an unremarkable one nevertheless. For a game that deals in a wheelhouse that includes William Gibson novels and Blade Runner, Binary Domain tells a reasonably interesting little story that's just the right blend of serious and Metal Gear-level ridiculousness. As an interesting example of Japan's attempt to appeal to a western market, Binary Domain is worth a look, Just don't look too closely else you might notice the hideous black haze that is intended to be occlusion around the characters and environmental set-dressing. If you're looking for a third-person shooter to help you forget that Gears of War 3 isn't on PC then this barely qualifies as a facsimile. It works (now Sega has done some work on the front end), the gameplay is passable, the robots blow apart real nice and Big-Bo is wonderful, but this is far from being best of breed.

reviewText:
I'm an American and I'm pretty tired of the stupid macho crap that gets written for the American G.I. characters in games and movies. I felt that both the dialog and the main character's personality were absolutely terrible. I've been around enlisted all my life and I've never heard anyone pull this stupid 'Gun-Ho' ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t without being dead within a few minutes of live fire. I guess if you're interested in a game written as if this was 'Expendables 7: NeoTokyo 2041' then this should do it. The character designs run the gauntlet of Good, Bad, Ugly as the gear design bounces between Functional and Cat Suit. The voice actors aren't terrible but the AI will badger you to hurry up you try and scavenge ammo or look for the dumb collectibles. The quick-time events were TERRIBLE and I would constantly die trying to figure out what the hell the prompts were trying to get me to do.

I'm getting tired, so I'm just going to rattle off all the other problems I had with the game:
Tired and broken main character tropes? CHECK!
Horrible voice command gimmick? CHECK!
Stupid 'collect X of Y' Achievements? CHECK!
Numerous online achievements on a DEAD game? CHECK!
Affection" grinding for best ending? CHECK!
Friendly AI that walks in front of your line of fire so you to loose affection? CHECK!
Strange control scheme from a console port? CHECK!
Strange controls paired with the worst quick-time prompts I've ever seen? WTF CHECK!

I'd only buy this for $1.50 to give to a pre-teen friend or family member. They'd probably not see the same faults that I do."

reviewText:
I don't recommend this game because of the following causes:

- You're always stuck with an AI companion and they are sometimes more hurtful than helpful; they get into your line of sight or they just run around.
- The cover is very clunky, you get stuck behind cover when you don't want to and viceversa.
- The weapon diversity is very limited.
- The story isn't that great, it's not bad but it's just not amazing.
- There are no settings for audio so sometimes you can get very loud sound effects/voices.

I would avoid this game given a second chance. Just my honest opinion, I know there are some loyal fans for this game though.

reviewText:
Given the meh-tacritic reviews this game had, I wasn't expecting too much.

Honestly, I can see why it wasn't scored so highly, but it is definitely lower than it deserves.

A lot of subsystems that don't offer much to the game, a deceptive lack of weapon variety, and bullet spongey enemies all mar a somewhat original, and not necessarily poor, third person shooter experience.

While the difficulty can be a bit random at times (soak up 100 bullets in one room, die in one hit 3 times in a row in the next), the story is engaging, has believable and likable characters, and an interesting look at transhumanism with a twist on the standard trope.

The game could have definitely done with better polish and playtesting, but it's by no means broken, and, if you can forgive it its flaws, there's no reason you will regret having played it.

reviewText: Preliminary review: Do not buy this game if you use mouse and keyboard to play shooters - it's broken in Binary Domain. I'm looking for a solution, but it's absolutely unplayable to some mouse acceleration / smoothing issue. Of course, this is due to it being an exceptionally lazy console to PC port. Had I known this game was a port at all, I probably wouldn't have even bothered. I'll update my review later if I get this game-breaking issue resolved.\n\nUPDATE: The only potential way to disable the mind-jarring, dizzying mouse acceleration is to install a third party program, or to PERMANENTLY change the way your mouse works in Windows using a registry hack. Nice SEGA. Well, this will be the last SEGA game that I buy. If you have a controller and like playing shooters that way, then it is /possibly/ a good game?? Otherwise: complete garbage port.

reviewText:
TL;DR
Gameplay: Repetetive cover shooting with annoying sidecharacters with nothing good to offer. Voice recognition doesn't work.
Story: Went from Interesting to dumb, fast. Over-the-top sequences made the game unbearable.
Writing: Horrible.
Design: Nicely designed stages and enemies.
Didn't bother playing online.

I bought this game during a sale and was reccomended saying this was an underrated game.
The Cyberpunk Neo-Tokyo setting had me interested so I thought I'd give it a try

It was awful. The more I played the game the more I cared less for the game then just wanting it to end.

I learned after installing the game that the game had a mandatory voice system in order to interact with the NPCs, after configuring my microphone I only found that it didn't recognize my speech, so i just outright turned it off.

The controls are clunky. I fight the controls so many times when they automatically put me against a wall, or when I try to aim, change positions etc.

Fighting enemies we're just repetative with slight variations in enemies once in a while. Although ammo was plentiful, enemies we're simply bullet-sponges and just made the pacing bad. Just because the enemies are robots doesn't excuse this fact.

Bosses we're hit or miss. mostly miss. Some bosses had interesting mechanics but the majority of them we're Shoot the glowing rainbow weakspot"
date: or "Shoot them until they die"\n\nI didn't bother upgrading weapons and I'm not sure nanomachines we're helpful or not. There was a bad ratio for the amount of money you'd get and how much upgrades and items cost
hoursPlayed: which eventually led me to have about 1mil by endgame.\n\nNext
voteText: the AI of your teammates. It was outright bothersome to deal with teammates. They keep repeating the same lines over and over and keep nagging at you and pretty much make you do all the work. Even while I fire at the enemy they just move around and move in front of me as I'm firing and then I get a negative trust indicator blaming me for poorly coded AI.\n\nAlso the "Trust system" or whatever does jack squat. All it does is make it likely that they follow your orders--which they never do regardless of how high the trust does. When saying lines like 'cover me' or 'fire' they seldom ever shoot more than 3 bullets at enemies only letting me take damage. And when you screw up
helpfulPercent: all they do is complain about how useless you are even though you we're doing all the work. I really wish you could team-kill / have an option to let them die during the game. I only felt unmotivated when having to choose partners. I just wished I could play the whole game solo.\n\nThe characters we're all so unlikeable in that there was nothing reddeming about them after all the nagging
votesHelpful: complaining
votesTotal: useless dialog
votesFunny:
boring backstories and unfunny quips. There are parts in the game where you have to rescue other memberss and I really wished there was an option to let them die and press on.

The music was really bland and overused throughout the game. Voice clips we're reused every single conflict and it only annoyed me every time I had to stop and defeat the enemies.

The story started with an interesting concept but go really poorly written as it went along. Unfortunatly talking about it would lead to spoilers
commentsCount: but all the "twists" while somewhat surprisng
column16:
it's the surprise you never asked for.
Also they blatantly rip off some parts of the story from other games.
The progression of the characters also had some really "jump-the-shark" moments with some really poorly written escapes and way too many plot holes and questionable events.

The only thing I really enjoyed we're the designs of bosses and the outside city. Nothing redeeming for the rest of the game whatsoever."

reviewText:
I gave it a fair shot to make a case for itself but in the end this game is almost worthless. Nonesense dialogue, terrible QTE scenes, awful story, mediocre gunplay. Plus it just has boggling bad design principles like weapon select always taking up your entire screen, inability to disable auto aim, and only being able to skip the soul crushingly bad cut scenes 90% of the time.

Do not buy this game, even during an excellent sale.

Edit: I also forgot about the horrible AI of your team constantly running face first into fire fights to stand and be shot to death. Do you love game over" screens beceause the dev team can't make a decent ally script?"

reviewText: Nah, don't bother.  The main character is utterly unlikeable, his partner Bo is basically a racist stereotype that emits a constant stream of outdated street slang and uses the word 'brother' (pronounced like 'my brotha!') more often than periods in any given sentence, the best nickname they can come up with for their robotic foe is 'scrap-heads'... it's that kind of game.\n\nThe controls are decent, although it's obvious you're playing a console port.  The special attack is charged by holding the middle mouse button, which is weird. You can use voice commands to order your team around, but I could only get the game to recognize maybe a third of what I said, so I had to use the manual command option instead. Your initial partner is a ridiculous version of the Black Heavy Weapons Guy stereotype. The game's campaign is SINGLE PLAYER ONLY - the co-op" Steam mentions is a "Horde" mode. reviewText: One of the most mediocre games I've ever played. Nothing works well -- not the boring combat, not the derivative futuristic setting, not the unceasing boss fights, nothing nada zip. The AI is brick-wall stupid, and team members will only follow the most basic commands until they lose complete focus and decide to take cover or launch straight into the enemy instead. The audio commands don't work properly, and getting the game to recognize what you're trying to say is nearly impossible without a high-end microphone. The Trust System adds absolutely nothing to the overall story arch besides making it harder to boss the AI team members around. Gamepad controls don't map properly. The setting is filled with nothing but constant grey-on-grey environments, and the characters are the kinds of shallow stereotypes that are so particular to Japanese games. Even worse, Binary Domain suffers from that horrible console affliction known as QTE-itis -- quicktime events and cut scenes dominate a exasperatingly large part of the game, and real playable action is rare.\n\nI'm boggled as to why such a mediocre game gets such good user reviews. It's as if people here have never played anything other than Gears of War or Azura's Wrath or other games of that ilk. Variety is the spice of life, folks, and the beauty about playing on an actual computer is that you have literally dozens of genres to choose from. Skip Binary Domain and play something better.
voteText: 9 of 24 people (38%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
On the positive side, it is a cyberpunk game with a story that relates a lot to Blade Runner and it took some risks building in a speech-recognition based team command system.

On the negative side, there is just too much american heroism served as dull humor, the controls, both with a gamepad and with mouse and keyboard don't feel right, the music, sound effects, voice actors and graphics are just mediocre and the previously mentioned voice-recognition doesn't work that good. Also I don't really like cover-based third-person shooters. And then it barely has 10 hours of campaign and no one plays the tacked-on multiplayer.

So all in all, it's an OK game, but I wouldn't really recommend it to anyone.
