reviewText:
N n n... NOPE!
Perfect example of an excellent game completely destroyed by lack of proper treatment during porting to PC. Mouse acceleration is abysmal and unbearable and joypad detection fails (buttons wrongly detected even with Xbox 360
controller emulator). Can you play this game - sure. Can you enjoy it? No.

It doesn't matter that this game has different dialogue lines that depend on your answers, voice control over friendly AI. It doesn't matter that you have nice guns, satysfying shooting, customization for both you and friendly AI, good models of enemies and friendlies, nano-machines (modifications), 2 AI to help you during missions (out of 6  accessible), big and diversified levels, iteresting bosses (even though I hate bosses with passion), a few difficulty levels.
It doesn't matter that graphics is nice, levels are long and environment is rich in details, effects are great, animations are awesome. Things around and characters sound good and convincing (even though they are cheesy as this is japanese game).

You just can't enjoy this game as controlling your character is pure pain and you want to it to go away. Save your money, time and frustration as you will be disappointed by the fact porting team didn't give proper treatment to this gem. It would be a great title, but in current state you do one thing - avoid it.

reviewText:
Almost the definition of mediocre. It doesn't do anything that hasn't already been done better before.

Shallow, dull characterization and a plot that can't decide if it wants to be serious (and typically luddite humanoid robots are immoral") or goofy all wrapped in some fairly generic third-person shooter gameplay that cribs thoroughly from other games.

It sure throws in just about everything too in the hopes that a decent game will emerge: you've got the dismemberment mechanic from Dead Space (but without the concept of alternate weak spots that made it interesting)
date: a light RPG system of character customization
recommended: selectible companions (with a "loyalty" system that will influence some of the cut-scenes and the ending)
hoursPlayed: some on-rails shooting sections
voteText: and most awkwardly of all a speech-recognition system (that never worked for me) for controlling the AI companions and answering occasional questions. Except while they were throwing all of this together they never thought about whether it improved the game or added anything. So it just feels very mashed together.\n\nThe levels are deeply linear and the settings aren't anything new or exceptional (slums

reviewText:
I do not recommend Binary Domain.

Binary Domain is a frustrating mix of a generic shooter, forgettable exposition spewing characters and a forced and unnatural microphone command input (which offers no new innovations over a Rainbow Six game on the original Microsoft xBox) in single player mode.

Nothing about the voice input system offers any value to the game whatsoever (identical interaction could have been achieved without it), and while the option to turn it off is available if you're determined enough, you're still left nagged and pestered by charmless characters.

Had there been an impressive breadth of distinctly different choices, each with unique consequences I could perhaps have been won over, but you're only given a narrow choice of the clearly manicly positive flattery, needlessly insulting negativity and always interpreted as passively aggressive insulting silence. That's an A, B, and C choice. Hell, if the game could detect overt sarcasm too it could have secured a place in my black little heart as a guilty pleasure. But no, nothing so entertaining or satisfying here.

Even without this boondoogle, the game's controls are somewhere between subpar and plain bad. During the (unskippable) tutorial at the start that has your elite covert infiltrator shooting roadsigns until they vanish, the tutorial unhelpfully provides instructions to the player to press the incorrect key, or even shows a symbol not vaguely resembling anything on my keyboard. It's a new twist on the worst kind of console-to-PC port; and its compounded by the charmless exposition teammate who switches between flattering the player and bemoaning like moody teenager whenever you aren't responding with wide-eyed positivity in a gamist pursuit of operant conditioning your teammate.

How the hell anyone thought a game about gun violence and infiltration would benefit from reassuring teammate's feelings and constant flow killing chitchat I don't have a clue.

To try and get around this mess, you may think going to the pause menu and swotting up on the controls would get you past this problem; but controls cannot be configured within the game and require an external configuration too.

Ultimately I'm glad I only got this as part of a game bundle and so mercifully I was not suckered into paying anything near full price. I strongly urge you to avoid spending your hard earned on this; to those who still feel this is a game they must play buy a second hand copy for the 360 or PS3 and spare yourself the full spectacle of tutorial so bad I quit it to do chores.

reviewText: If you're going to get this game, don't get it on PC. Fun gameplay, good core concept, good story, but seriously broken PC controls. Mouse sensitivity is INSANELY high, and there's no option to change it in the settings menu (what kind of shooter doesn't let you change the sensitivity?) so I figured I'd just plug in a 360 controller instead; except the game has no controller support; if you try and use one, all of othe controls on the right stick will be totally flopped, and I couldn't find any way to change this anywhere. This is a solid game, but it's absolutely broken to play on PC.

reviewText: The core shooting gameplay is good. The trust system is okay, certainly a step above the usual shooter, but don't expect anything like Mass Effect or Alpha Protocol here. Where this game really shows its flaws is in the boss fights and special sequences. The boss fights require you to shoot small objects that are moving at high speeds, or to expose yourself to massive barrages of insta-kill missiles, or to get punched in the face by gigantic robots a lot before you can ever shoot at the boss once. The special sequences involve bad camera angles, odd controls, trial & error, and the like.\n\nYou can get the story & companion dialogue by watching a longplay on Youtube, so you should avoid buying it unless it goes on sale.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying that the premise for this game is fantastic! A future where robots can look and act just like humans, to the point that the robots themselves actually believe they are alive. Such robots are outlawed, a violation of global law, but someone is producing them, and it‘s your job to find out who it is, stop them, and destroy every robot you find on your way. But how do you know who these robots are? They could be all round you. Who can you trust? Can you even be sure you aren’t one? It’s a setting ripe for suspicion, deep contemplation into the nature of life, and gripping moral choices. And the story and general aesthetic were absolutely brilliant!

That said, the implementation could have been a whole lot better. The game turned out to be VERY linear, which is not necessarily a bad thing (Spec Ops: The Line was very linear, and I consider it to be a masterpiece), but something about this game felt slightly off. Maybe it was because of the unholy amount of inescapable boss fights. Maybe it was that the suspicion of this world didn’t seem as prevalent as it could or should have been. Or maybe it was that any potential tough choices (and there were a lot) were made for you in the cut-scenes, leaving you powerless to the whim and fancy of the game.

The trust mechanic, which could have had so much potential, turned out to be little more than shoot the enemy to gain trust with your squad, and shoot your squad to lose that trust (which was easy to do, since they seem to have a habit of running in front of you in combat). You can also talk to your squad and choosing the right response will net you some more trust, but you are never able to intervene or choose sides when your squad has a argument, so it becomes just a matter of just agreeing with whoever you’re currently talking to, even if it goes against what you‘ve just told another squad-mate. And the more trust you have with your squad, the better an ending you get.

But the absolute biggest problem was the inconsistent characterization. I couldn’t ever really take the protagonist seriously, which is a shame because he had some deep revelations and some truly heart-wrenching moments. But the rest of the time he was making sarcastic and juvenile wise-crack comments in a attempt to...to…I don’t really know why. It did absolutely nothing for the story or the endearment of his character, the only thing it did accomplish was to tear me out of my immersion almost every time he opened his mouth. The other characters were slightly better, but they weren’t immune to the bad writing either, and there were times when they all devolved to nothing more than stereotypes; Big Beefy African-American guy with a machine gun, hot Asian sniper, no-nonsense British agent, etc.

Do I recommend it? That’s a hard one. For most people I would say no, there are tons of better games out there more worthy of you‘re time. But for anyone (like me) that enjoys seeing what the medium potentially could be capable of doing, and wants to play through a game that almost got there, then yes, play it. Because while this review may sound extremely negative, I actually did have some good moments with this game. It was good, it just wasn’t all that it could have been, which is sad, because it could have been incredible!

reviewText: A flawed game with an interesting story and twist at the end. However, gameplay is lackluster and plagued by idiotic companion AI, and clumbsy controls. Boss battles are also sometimes non-sensical. This game also features bullet sponge humans with auto-heal that inexplicably get wounded by a single bullet during cutscenes.\n\nIf you want a game with good companion AI, play Star Wars Republic Commando. If you want to a game with good 3rd person cover shooter mechanics, play Deus Ex: Human Revolution. Binary Domain is only recommended for those with the patience of a Saint or desperate need for a fix of robot smashing.

reviewText:
A broken experience is the best way I could describe this.

The button prompts don't match to the default buttons.  The voice commands are absolute crap, and there's no way to disable them.  The game casually reminds you that a microphone is not needed, but it will make the game more difficult.  Absolutely backwards controls destroy any other positive aspects of the game.  To top it all of the quick time events that completely screw up the game's flow are painfully reminiscent of the 90's,

Don't spend your money on this game.  There are a dozen better games, and if you really want this experience done right I'd recommend Gears opf War.

reviewText:
OKAY THIS REVIEW IS HALF AND HALF. I partially recommend based on certain conditions.

1. You need a good headset with a clear high quality microphon attachment.

You cannot enjoy this game or play it well without it. Binary Domain rely's on your vocal input and if it cannot hear you well or it constantly picks up audio from something else your gonna have a bad time. Yes you have the option to turn this feature off but that doesn't keep the game from still requiring you to use the feature, you just turned off your mic and the game still waits for you to respond.

This game has so much potential but it gets bogged down by the jankey voice command mechanic. If you have a really good mic, and headphone setup then I recommend the game, if you do not I ask that you don't waste your time and avoid it.

reviewText:
This is a good third person shooter, not the best in ANY way... but it's good fun. Has got a decent story, at least three good characters (one of the characters I didn't care about AT ALL) and fun gameplay.

In the future, the world has been flooded due to global warming and since most of us humans died during the flooding, robots are created to be used to rebuild the cities. The concerns about the economy of the world lead to the NEW Geneva Convention... and one of the clauses of that is the banning of research that could pass human in intelligence. But the story really begins when the headquarter of the Bergen company gets attacked by an android, sent from their rivals - Amada. Due to that attack, you - Dan Marshall - and your Rust Crew gets sent to Japan to bring Amada in for questioning... and the ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan... so to speak.

I had fun with this title and it's a shame there won't be a sequel since the ending is close to a cliffhanger. I guess you can't have everything in the world.

reviewText:
I Highly reccomend this game. This game is under rated.

Just to mention, this game is not rich with history, however does have a good backstory, and creates a amazing base for potential future development of story/universe, if this was to pass onto other games or any movie.

For a game that is 2 years old, it holds decent graphics where it deserves it, very much fun gameplay and mostly revolves around squad leading. This game is entertaining and fun, while exciting and requiring you to play differently with each enemy you encounter, and the locations will change going through the stages, providing different types of hazards along the way, placing you in different scenarios as well, that can also affect the type of squad member following you. Won't go into further detail.

The backstory is a good base, and key points in the story you can sometimes predict the plot twists and sometimes be surprised by them. This game doesn't really have much features that would affect the story, to possibly change the ending BUT I COULD BE WRONG, I am not 100% on this. In the end, it will have created a base for future development of a great universe, but as much as it appears it will not continue, it would still be amazing.

For a game that isn't over the top in graphics, features, or complex backstory/history, it does it all very well, and very entertaining to the look and theme of this game, and some point keeps true to a few things, while throwing in some ecentric" things in for entertainment purposes. reviewText: This is a yes with a few caveats.... The usual language for keys are different such as mouse wheel being abreviated mswhl or something its M. I spent 10 minutes in a tutorial pressing the M key trying to reload before I figured it out. I opted out of the voice option system as it never recognized anything I said. I also never used the team commands at all. I basically shot whatever moved and the team ai did what they do. Other than little niggles like that, its a fun shooter. The story is servicable and the shooting is solid. The different guns are fun to play with and the different bosses are fun to fight. There were only a few cases where this game suffered from resident evil 5 boss syndrome where you defeat him and he comes back and you do it over and over again. I would say if this is on sale for 10 bucks or less its worth your time.

reviewText:
I'm glad that I could eventually finish this game after I dropped it for unknown reason few years ago.

Story is much longer than what I expected. Scrapped about 7 hrs of Single Player campaign,

Story is ok. Robots are conquering the world and we must stop them at all cost. Blah blah blah.
First half is boring. Near end-game is quite good. Voice acting is okay....

Voice command is the worst thing ever invented in game industry. Nice concept, but I ever want to speak in the game I would do it TeamSpeak with friends instead.

Extreme linear gameplay. VERY repetitive

Shooting robot is not FUN. They are super hard to die. And we have over 100+ of the same freaking green and red robot to shoot.

Only things that keep me playing this game was... I want to know the ending.

Never play it with Keyboard and Mouse, Cuz the game is designed for Controller. Plugged the Controller in and it still show keyboard command on screen. Well I could fix it using setting menu, but Why can't they make it auto.

7/10 (lower if play with KB/M)

Not bad but not that great. Please buy only when there's a deal.

reviewText:
Honestly I don't understand why this game keeps such a low profile.

Pro:
+ voice command/talk feature
+ above average graphics
+ atmospheric
+ good animations
+ great musical score and sound effects
+ very good voice acting (english)
+ Fluent and linear gameplay (I like linear games)
+ nice boss fights
+ some choices change the following events (several endings)
+ interaction with the crewmembers
+ 10h of dense and varied playing time (I also like games that aren't prolonged artificially)

Cons:
- story is somewhat abstruse (at least to me)
- feels sometimes more like a shooter, no real strategies necessary
- rpg-like character development feels irrelevant

Verdics:
This was the first time for me that I played a game where I actually talked/gave commands to my AI-crewmates using the mike of my headset (alternatively you can also use keyboard commands). Felt odd in the beginning, but after a while it is fun and I got a hang on it.
If you like games such as Mass Effect, grab this one when it's on sale. You won't regret it.

reviewText:
Binary Domain is not a perfect game. While there are some nuisance points to this 3rd person shooter. There are also some bright spots, that make this worth checking out.

Cons:
1) Partners are a bit naggy. They will repeat phrases like, This way." or "Let's go!" while you
explore for items.
2) The AI is pretty dumb & will frequently run into your line of fire. Not only that
date:
they will blame
you for their error & you will lose their favor. This is not a huge problem unless you have
incredibly bad aim or are blatantly firing on your team.
3) The key prompts are terribly mislabeled
recommended:
while playing with a game controller. It can get
confusing at times & can mess you up at some points.

Pros:
1) Good play mechanics. Cover system & combat are pretty well done.
2) Intriguing story with variations based on favor with individual teammates.
3) The characters are likable.
4) Audio & visuals are still pretty damn good even though this game is pretty dated.

This is not a bad buy at $14.99. If you're still hesitant. Snatch it up fast when it goes on sale."

reviewText: Actaully kind of like this game. It's a pretty straight-forward cover shooter but being that it's Sega developed, it's kind of an arcade-y ride. Just make sure you TURN OFF the voice commands because that functionality is broken at worst and inconsistent at best. You can use TAB to talk to your teammates instead. Also you can't configure many options in the game itself, you have to lauch the configuration tool separately, which, again, you should definitely do first. It's not worth it for more than $10, but if you manage to get it on a good sale and you have nothing else to play and like shooters then give it a shot. There's also a demo, but if I recall correctly, the conrols felt REALLY bad in the demo so it's not a very good indication of how movement and aiming feels in game.

reviewText: This game is beautiful, fairly straight forward, great cinematics, in-game visuals, UI, and sounds. At times will get your heart pumping. Giant bosses and fairly humorous dialogue. reviewText:
The first time I´ve played the demo version of Binary Domain on the PS3, I didn´t like the feeling of the game and deleted the demo.
Last year I got the game for free from the german PC mag Gamestar" and I thought I ditched the disc after watching the videos on it but found it last week among my other PC games.

I thought: "Come on! One more try!" and I´m glad I gave the game a second chance!

The game itself is a pretty basic 3rd Person cover shooter like Gears of War or Spec Ops The Line
date: but I fired more bullets in one playthrough than in the 4 Gears games and Spec Ops together and I never killed (or destroyed) so many enemys in one playthrough of a game
recommended:
except for the serious sam games of course.

Unlike the other famous Covershooters you can interact with your comrades and they respond to your actions and behavior. Sometimes they ask you a question and if you agree with them the like you and follow your orders or if you ♥♥♥♥ them off by shooting them or say something rude they refuse.
In my opionion thats pretty pointless. They always catched a few bullets from me
hoursPlayed: because they ran in my line of fire. But when you speak with them just agree with everything and it´s okay again.\n\nAnd unlike the other shooters you can upgrade your main rifle with credits you earn by shooting robots. There are so many enemys that you can easily afford all the upgrades and get an overpowered rifle. At first you need to shoot different body parts to bring a robot down
voteText: because your rifle is very weak. At about half of the game I destroyed enemy groups within seconds and even bossfights were over in minutes. But shooting different bodyparts has also different effects. Shoot their legs and they can only crawl anymore
helpfulPercent: shoot their head and they start to attack each other.\nAt the beginning this was very helpful
votesHelpful: but like I said
votesTotal: at half of the game you have a very strong rifle.\n\nYou can also upgrade the guns of your comrades
votesFunny:
but I never did that except for the last part of the game when I couldn´t upgrade my rifle anymore but I didn´t have the feeling that my comrades fight more effective after that.
Sometimes you find upgrades for your character and the comrades too. I found some upgrades just at the beginning and after that stopped looking.

The game is very easy. I started on survivor difficulty and I never had any problems with any part of the game.

The story is pretty good. It may not win a price
commentsCount: but thanks to it´s likeable characters it´s better than you´re average shooter story and it keeps you going.\n\nOverall Binary Domain is a very fun shooter and I enjoyed playing it for about 10 hours."

reviewText: Fun combat system, and great weapon feel, makes this 3rd person shoot a blast to play. You get to fight large bosses, and upgrade your character and weapons (rpg light). There is also a trust system, your teammates trust you based upon your performance and answers in small talk. High trust means they will actually listen to your commands, low trust means they will refuse. It really doesn't matter, because they are utterly useless anyway. The story might be considered weak and brain dead, but I don't mind because I prefere that kind of story.\n\nI finished the game in two days (10 hours), it's not very often I play a game from start to finish so quick (I might not even play through it at all). Which means I had a great time playing it. There is a multiplayer part that I haven't testet yet, I bet it's some kind of hoard mode.

reviewText: For anybody who loves shooters, especially cover shooters like Gears of War or even the Sci-Fi RPG/Shooter blended Mass Effect, this game is for you. The game's setting is in a near-future Japan where a fictional corporation, the Amada corporation, is illegally (illegal due to a Geneva convention clause) creating near-human-like robots called Hollow Children". You
date: Dan and your team from around the world i.e. a "Rust Crew" are sent in to arrest Amada. This new Japan's government is very totalitarian where the rich elite rule and the whole country is securely guarded by humans and robots alike (compliments from Amada) so be prepared for action.\n\nThe gameplay offers a lot of enemy and scenario variety- from taking on hordes of robot infantries to fighting a huge killing machine in a large open space to being in a moving vehicle where robots are lining up as target practice. While it's deceivingly just a well-done arcade-y cover'n'shoot kind of game
recommended: there is one feature that sets it apart- teamwork. The game allows you to interact with your AI companions either through a microphone
hoursPlayed: albeit mediocre
voteText: or a selection of options you can choose with keys or buttons. It adds a layer of interest to the game and it's nice to actually seeing your teammates actually interacting with the game instead of sitting there like Christmas ornaments (I'm looking at you Call of Duty).\n\nI originally had played the demo on the PS3 awhile ago but never wanted to pay for new price. Finally bought this while on sale for $3; it's easily worth that and honestly even paying full price would be satisfying. There are some minor weird annoyances- running down stairs = hopping
helpfulPercent: instances where boss enemies immobilize you again right after healing
votesHelpful: teammates not healing you when you're immobilized
votesTotal: but it's worth it for the solid arcade action it offers. Either plug in a 360 controller or use your mouse and KB and play this bad boy!"

reviewText:
I recommend this, but with hesitation. I bought this game for $4, so at that price, yes I would recommend it. However, I would not recommend it if it were purchased for more than $8.

Here is the good: The graphics. They are mostly excellent. Sometimes the rendering shows more fake looking reflections and glare but it is not that bad. Overall the textures and polygon count are quite high. You have a limited arsenal, but you can swap out some of your seconday guns and grenedes as you find them. I watch a lot of anime and for some reason this whole game feels like something I had watched previously, or some combination of them. It is like a combination of Vexille, Appleseed, Ghost in the Shell and various others, along with a sort of terminator vibe. The game plot is different from many others I have played in the past few years. The voice acting is very good and Dan's voice is done by a guy who does lots of anime.

Here is the not so good: Clunky controls. There is a button you can use to hide behind a wall or barrier, but no way to crouch. No button to prone or sprint either. Also, you cannot change these controls on the fly. You have to exit the game and use a seprate configuration program to change it. A bit of a pain. The configuration seems 'light' in the audio aspect - one master control for all volume but not for effects, voices, music, etc. You also cannot set the 'enter' key to examine. There is also a weird mouse acceleration thing going on - I move with my mouse and it jerks the view really quick. No way to adjust this which seems strange for a shooter. In some parts of the game (car chase scene I think) it is turned off and your turn rate seems incredibly slow. The AI - specifically your teammates, seems incredibly stupid. Here I am sniping or shooting away and my teammates run right into my line of fire, and then complain to me for hitting them. There is also the whole team interaction speech thing. Sometimes your mate starts yapping and asks you handled yourself really good back there" or something like that. One response may be "no problem". Another time I was told we need to protect a teammate and the reponses available were "Sh!t" "Damn it" or "I got it" It just seems like the dialogue is a little strange. The whole chatting with your team feels pretty unnecessary during the downtime. It may help in some cases during battle to make them charge or fall back
hoursPlayed: if ever
voteText: used it outside of the required times I had to respond. There are also other cutscenes that require user input to finish
helpfulPercent: and if you fail
votesHelpful: you die and have to redo. I would much rather just  relax for a minute and watch the screen instead. There is also some sort of loyalty meter going on. This game is trying too hard to give you RPG aspects that are completely unnecessary. Your actions (not killing enough
votesTotal: friendly fire) or responding in a bad way could lower this. Just seems tacked on. You also get points/credits on killing robots and you can use that to upgrade weapons
votesFunny: supplies and other various things. In conjunction with having multiple teammates and choosing which are in your squad it sort of reminded me of Mass Effect
commentsCount: but a very very light version. Also

reviewText:
The year is 2080 and most of the planet have suffered disastersous floods and rising sea levels caused by accellerated effects of global warming melting both polar caps drowning a big chunk of the human population in lowlands, destroying infrastructure and buildings.

Technological breaktroughs in robotics enabled Amada who built the first humanoid robot equipped with advanced AI, and later the US robotic manufacturer Bergen to cash in when countries all over the world started buying massive amounts of robots in an effort to replace the human workforce.

In the process of rebuilding many humans became unemployed, poor and neglected by the goverment. Forced to seek shelter in the underbelly, beneeth the ruins of Tokyo and the old metro which common people share with organized crime syndicates, drug cartells, black markets and armed guerilla resistance fighters, at war with the goverment.


When Bergen HQ is attacked by a robotic humanoid convinced he is human. The UNSC orders the IRTA task-force to deploy in Japan and find Amada and question him.
The task-force the Rust Crew" is a multinational collection of mercs
date: ex-US Army/MI6/PLA and a Bergen battle droid from French special forces.\n\nBD is a 3rd person linear tactical shooter with some RPG elements incorporated in the game such as the ability to  distribute skills to the diffrent characthers weapon systems
recommended: tweak characters in your group with physical and mental enhancing nanomachines. There is also sort of a trust-based consequence system. Your performance and how you treat your teammates have an effect on your teammates' willingness to respond to your commands and the cutscenes displayed by the game

reviewText: At First I did not like this game based on the Demo and pretty much people saying how horrible the controls are.\nHowever that being said I played it with a mouse and keyboard. . . no problem with controls what so ever. Haven't tried with a Controler yet but I might to see how it plays out. This game how ever had such a great story behind it. I'm a sucker for japanese Animation movies like Appleseed, Vexille and lets throw in Ghost in the Shell. I love my Scifi as much as any one so my reccommendation might be a bit bias. The bottom line is I had fun in the game. Some Boss fights I would get hit,hit,hit then need a revive and when I do I get hit again to need another revive. . . a little annoying but not enough to get me mad or stop playing. I liked the twist they added and the characters development pretty much was good with a bit of bad. The Campaign is a bit short but I burned through this game quickly because I really wanted to beat it. The plot/story is to blame for that. I will say that some of the weapons could have been better. Upgrade feature could use work. Only the main weapon of each character can be upgraded and I would of like my side arm to be upgraded but can't complain too much about it. Also the Trust feature with each character. I had all main character MAX out with Trust and yet I don't know what its really for. I don't know if they do better in combat or what so seem like a dead feature to have in the game. But I don't enjoy as many games as I use to or want to keep playing it all the way through. How ever I really did in fact enjoy this game. Not the best 3rd person game I have ever played but I enjoyed it and got this when it was on sale so I have no buyer remorse. I actually thought when buying this game I would of just have paid for another game that will sit in my list of games unfinished because I didn't enjoy it enough to finish it. This was not the case.\nOne of the biggest things that really kept this game interesting was the Boss fights. Pretty straight forward but no real push over and some times I felt like my attempt to stop/destroy them was not being effective. Not the case but it was sort of a fun feeling to have. Left me on the edge a bit for a few fights. I highly Recommend this to any one who have similar taste in story. Not a long story but I would say worth the buy.(for sure worth the buy if its on sale)

reviewText:
Binary Domain doesn't really add anything new to the shooter genre, but it executes on established mechanics extremely well. The shooting is extremely satisfying with chunks of metal flying off your robotic foes with each bullet. Enemy behavior changes depending on where you shoot them. Shooting off a leg causes a robot to crawl at you for a close attack while shooting off a robot's head causes it to shoot at friend and foe alike.

Other features such as purchaseable upgrades for your guns, your character, and your allies help enhance the sense of progress through the game. There is trust system in the game that aims to add a sense of depth and connection to your NPC allies. Trust isn't very important to the core gameplay, but having a certain trust level with certain allies does affect your game ending, which adds some replayability.

Binary Domain is a strong 3rd person shooter with a great story, corny writing, and fun characters.

reviewText: Addictive gameplay + good story = what else do you need from a game? 8/10
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Binary Domain is a third-person shooter from Sega set in a robot-filled future earth. When the Amada Corporation appears to have violated international law against the creation of realistic, human-like robots, a small squad of elite soldiers are sent to infiltrate Japan to arrest the corp's CEO. The story feels weak and cliched towards the beginning, so for the first few hours the game mostly rides on its gameplay.

And what gameplay it is! Binary Domain's combat is the star of the show and is defined by its robotic enemies. Your foes are all loaded with destructible parts that influence behavior as they are destroyed. Blast a robot's shooting arm off? It'll have to pause to reach down and pick his gun back up in his other arm? Remove the legs? Watch the bot slowly crawl along the ground with its arms to get to you. Headshot? It'll start blasting its teammates in confusion. Being able to manipulate the enemies through mutilation enables a variety of great tricks. In an ordinary fight, you'll mostly just aim for headshots, but when you need to move to a new vantage point or rush past enemies, being able to disable them with shots to the arms or a spray at the legs is great fun and quite useful.

The bosses are similarly destructible, featuring tons of parts for you to shoot through as you slowly dismantle them from gargantuans into scrap heaps. The bosses are all memorable and are real showstoppers, usually being both massive and cleverly designed.

Even outside the destructible enemies and great bosses, the game's design is quite impressive. You have a variety of squad members you can choose to bring with you, and who you bring and how you communicate with them will influence both their respect for you and which ending of the game you receive. Vending stations provide a way to upgrade you and your squadmates' weapons. Gameplay gets broken up with little minigame sections like driving boats through absurdly spacious sewers.  There's even an option to communicate with your squad members using voice recognition, rather than menu responses. Token multiplayer is also included (but I didn't even check it, probably dead by now).

If there are any real deficiencies in the game, they are in the voice recognition and gun upgrades. The voice recognition isn't really bad, per se, it's just not nearly as efficient as using the menu responses. It doesn't help that talking to a computer program feels hopelessly awkward. As for the upgrades, the unfortunate reality is that your main rifle will, after a few hours, become absurdly good. So good that you'll actively try to avoid using other weapons in favor of it.

So the core gameplay is great other than a few minor quibbles, which is great, because it helps carry you through far enough to start appreciating the story. I felt that Binary Domain's plot started off weak. The characters felt cliched and being dumped into this weird almost-post-apocalyptic-but-not-quite universe didn't help.  However, after a little bit of time with the game, I began to really warm to my squadmates and found the wild plot twists very engaging. It's good science fiction that presents an interesting world with good characters and a fun plot that gives you a moment to reflect on on themes dealing with the nature of humanity.

So whether you want a good story or just want to turn hundreds of robots into piles of metallic shavings, Binary Domain will not disappoint.

reviewText: For anybody who loves shooters, especially cover shooters like Gears of War or even the Sci-Fi RPG/Shooter blended Mass Effect, this game is for you. The game's setting is in a near-future Japan where a fictional corporation, the Amada corporation, is illegally (illegal due to a Geneva convention clause) creating near-human-like robots called Hollow Children". You
date: Dan and your team from around the world i.e. a "Rust Crew" are sent in to arrest Amada. This new Japan's government is very totalitarian where the rich elite rule and the whole country is securely guarded by humans and robots alike (compliments from Amada) so be prepared for action.\n\nThe gameplay offers a lot of enemy and scenario variety- from taking on hordes of robot infantries to fighting a huge killing machine in a large open space to being in a moving vehicle where robots are lining up as target practice. While it's deceivingly just a well-done arcade-y cover'n'shoot kind of game
recommended: there is one feature that sets it apart- teamwork. The game allows you to interact with your AI companions either through a microphone
hoursPlayed: albeit mediocre
voteText: or a selection of options you can choose with keys or buttons. It adds a layer of interest to the game and it's nice to actually seeing your teammates actually interacting with the game instead of sitting there like Christmas ornaments (I'm looking at you Call of Duty).\n\nI originally had played the demo on the PS3 awhile ago but never wanted to pay for new price. Finally bought this while on sale for $3; it's easily worth that and honestly even paying full price would be satisfying. There are some minor weird annoyances- running down stairs = hopping
helpfulPercent: instances where boss enemies immobilize you again right after healing
votesHelpful: teammates not healing you when you're immobilized
votesTotal: but it's worth it for the solid arcade action it offers. Either plug in a 360 controller or use your mouse and KB and play this bad boy!"

reviewText:
While a short game it's cool! The game has implemented in voice commands, however they don't seem to work so well, so relying on them can be annoying.

But other then that the game is fun. You never actually kill a single human behing in this game, but simply robots. However the fighting is extremely enjoyable. This also includes large boss fights many times through out the game. The fights aren't super hard but can be tricky. They are also really enjoyable.

Would I pay full price for this game? Probably not. But if it's on sale, I'd suggest picking it up as it's a lot more enjoyable then it may seem

reviewText: Funny, plenty of action, good plot and overall a great game. The game reminds me of a good old action movie from the 90s, the game itself is not too difficult, but there is alot of explosions, gun fire, cliché moments and jokes. Gameplay wise it sorta plays like Mass Effect. but maybe thats just me. Deffinetly  recommend to anyone who wants to live through captivating and light action game.

reviewText:
Do you like Gears of War? Do you like Vanquish? Do you feel like you need 9 hours of gun-totting, japanese influenced and robot purging fun? Then Binary Domain is for you!
It's like Gears of War! (but not as terrible)
It's like Vanquish! (but sadly not CURAYZAY)
And its a bit like Dead Space with strategic root n tooty gun shooty at robotic enemies limbs, which add a layer of strategy to the actual gameplay, finding out which glowing thing to blast on the vast amount of enemies you'll face.
The story is great as well with many TWEEESTS and turns that'll keep you on the edge of your chair.
Too bad it'll never get a sequel, goddamit SEGA.

reviewText: The game is fairly linear, which is a downer with all of these open world games we have now. It is also fairly short, running about 8 hours if you don't blitz through every level. Voice recognition is horrible, don't use it. Other than those quirks the game is very enjoyable and was worth the buy/playthrough. Fans of games like Mass Effect will enjoy it.
